description: WHAT THE QURAN MEANT And Why It Matters By Garry Wills 226 pp. Viking. $25.

title: Even on Christmas Eve, Criminals Dont Take a Holiday
description: On the twelfth day of Christmas, my writers gave to me: twelve stalkers stalking, eleven burglars burgling, ten sleuths a-sleuthing, nine creeps a-creeping, eight looters looting, seven broken toys, six screaming kids, five overcooked birds, four stolen presents, three drunken uncles, two dead Santas and a madman swinging from a pear tree.

title: Without New Laws or Walls, Trump Presses the Brake on Legal Immigration
description: A scientist recruited by the renowned Cleveland Clinic is stuck in India because his visa is delayed. An entrepreneur courted by Silicon Valley companies had his application denied. Many green card applicants have new interviews to pass.

title: Beavers Emerge as Agents of Arctic Destruction
description: Want the latest climate news in your inbox? You can sign up here to receive Climate Fwd:, our new email newsletter.

title: G.O.P. Finally Notches 2017 Victory While Bracing for 2018 Verdict
description: WASHINGTON  It was an unsightly and painful yearlong slog, but Republicans are finally getting what they so desperately craved  a major legislative victory in the form of a consequential tax overhaul.

title: In Protests of Net Neutrality Repeal, Teenage Voices Stood Out
description: WASHINGTON  When Anooha Dasari, 16, heard the federal government was about to kill rules that guaranteed an open internet, she contacted her United States representatives for the first time, asking them to stop the action.

title: We Sponsor Refugees. What to Do About Their Patriarchal Ways?
description: I am a member of a group that has sponsored a family of refugees from rural Syria. When the family arrived, group members signed up all four children  two boys and two girls  for soccer programs. Various group members also offered to drive the kids to soccer, only to find that on nights when the girls were to participate, the parents always made some excuse about why their daughters couldnt go. It didnt take long for us to realize that in their family, girls arent allowed to participate in programs outside of the home, a decidedly nonegalitarian attitude if there ever was one. Heres the dilemma: There are those who dont want to enroll any of the children in future recreational programs because of the familys highly conservative attitudes toward females. Others feel that this would make the group guilty of imposing its value system on a refugee family and, by extension, just end up hurting the young sons. Whos right?

title: Elizabeth Banks Was a Frustrated Actress. Now Shes a Determined Mogul.
description: LOS ANGELES  Elizabeth Banks doesnt mince words. Why bother, when youre trying to get things done? Sitting in her office, in a bungalow on the Universal Studios lot here, the platform heels she wore for a photo shoot replaced with black oxfords, Ms. Banks, 43, was no-nonsense when asked why she transformed herself from a comic star into a producer and director.

title: An Ancient Egyptian City Stays Vibrant
description: No one knows for certain how the destruction of the Library of Alexandria played out, but the extent of the loss is indisputable. Thousands upon thousands of irreplaceable scrolls, books and letters burned when Julius Caesar set fire to the fleet of Ptolemy XIII. The blaze spread from the dockyards and destroyed the great library, according to Plutarch, possibly consuming works from Homer, Euripides and Sophocles  maybe even the personal library of Aristotle himself.

title: How This Lithuanian Outpost Lured LiAngelo and LaMelo Ball
description: PRIENAI, Lithuania  It was only fitting, perhaps, that an intercontinental escapade exhibiting the awesome power of the present day sports-celebrity-industrial complex began with a late-night direct message on Twitter.

title: Jimmy Fallon Says the Tax Bill Is Actually Meant as Punishment
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: Even Imperfect Algorithms Can Improve the Criminal Justice System
description: In courtrooms across the country, judges turn to computer algorithms when deciding whether defendants awaiting trial must pay bail or can be released without payment. The increasing use of such algorithms has prompted warnings about the dangers of artificial intelligence. But research shows that algorithms are powerful tools for combating the capricious and biased nature of human decisions.

title: The Ghoulish Pursuit of Executing a Terminally Ill Inmate
description: When judges schedule a lethal injection for a terminally ill prisoner whose struggle against lymphatic cancer and extensive medical history has left him without any easily accessible veins, our law descends into a ghoulish inferno. It is a dreadful place where our most august jurists ruminate over catheter gauges and needle sizes, and ponder whether to slice deep into the groin or puncture internal jugular veins. History will not judge us favorably.

title: The Tax Bill Shows the G.O.P.s Contempt for Democracy
description: The Republican Tax Cuts and Jobs Act is notably generous to corporations, high earners, inheritors of large estates and the owners of private jets. Taken as a whole, the bill will add about $1.4 trillion to the deficit in the next decade and trigger automatic cuts to Medicare and other safety net programs unless Congress steps in to stop them.

title: Why Sitting May Be Bad for Your Heart
description: Sitting quietly for extended periods of time could be hurting your heart, according to a surprising new study. It finds that the more people sit, the greater the likelihood that they will show signs of injury to their heart muscles.

title: Debunking Myths About Estrangement
description: Its the classic image of the holidays: Parents, siblings and their children gather around the family table to feast and catch up on one anothers lives. But it doesnt always work that way.

title: Murray Hill, Manhattan: Where the Old and New Meet
description: Murray Hill is a fast-growing area where many sleek new buildings have recently opened, or will soon. But most of the new structures, including high-rise condos and rental buildings, are between Third Avenue and the East River. West of Third, many buildings have landmark status or are part of a historic district with graceful rowhouses, stately mansions and stables or carriage houses turned into homes.

title: Republicans Despise the Working Class, Continued
description: The GOP tax plan is remarkably unpopular. According to the latest NBC poll, only 24% of the public thinks its a good idea; 63% believe that its mainly for the rich and corporations [editor: it is], while only 7% think its aimed at the middle class. Republicans think it will become more popular over time; thats not what happened with previous tax cuts, and as Drew Altman of Kaiser Family Foundation notes, everyone  even Republicans  hates the idea of cutting major social programs to pay for tax cuts, which is exactly what the GOP plans to do.

description: John Latouche, a prolific lyricist of Broadways golden age, had an omnivorous taste in art and friends. He worked with Duke Ellington and Leonard Bernstein, supported John Cage and Ellsworth Kelly and hosted salons at which Carol Channing might rub elbows with Jean-Paul Sartre.

title: 10 More Plays Where the Future Forecast Is Grim
description: Robert OHaras world-without-women satire Mankind is the latest play to see the future through a lighting gel darkly. Over the last decade, many writers have imagined grim prospects for America, Britain and the world. In recent years, they have come faster. And maybe even bleaker. Here are 10 (of many) theatrical dystopias.

title: A New Russian Ploy: Competing Extradition Requests
description: MOSCOW  The Russian spam kingpin had long been in the cross hairs of the F.B.I., and agents finally got their shot when the man scheduled a vacation in Spain. At the agencys request, Spanish security officers in April arrested the man, Pyotr Y. Levashov, who is accused of stuffing untold millions of inboxes with ads for pornography, pills and penny stocks.

title: School Sex-Abuse Report Shows Difficulty of Substantiating Claims

title: Susan Rice: When America No Longer Is a Global Force for Good
description: President Trumps National Security Strategy marks a dramatic departure from the plans of his Republican and Democratic predecessors, painting a dark, almost dystopian portrait of an extraordinarily dangerous world characterized by hostile states and lurking threats. There is scant mention of Americas unrivaled political, military, technological and economic strength, or the opportunities to expand prosperity, freedom and security through principled leadership  the foundation of American foreign policy since World War II.

description: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Hiroko Tabuchi, a climate and environment reporter for The Times, discussed the tech shes using.
