description: Alexander Payne narrates a sequence from his film featuring Matt Damon and Hong Chau.

title: Cuba Delays End of Ral Castros Presidency by Two Months
description: Cubas leader, Ral Castro, will step down as president in April, roughly two months later than anticipated, the government announced on Thursday.

title: Eric Schmidt to Step Down as Alphabets Executive Chairman
description: Eric Schmidt joined Google in 2001 to provide what amounted to adult supervision for the companys young founders, Larry Page and Sergey Brin. He helped take Google public in 2004 and built it into a colossus. In 2011, after being appointed executive chairman, he became a prominent emissary for the company to Washington.

title: Tax Cuts Crystallize Haves, Wants, Cants, Wonts
description: The cut in the American corporate tax rate to 21 percent from 35 percent is a windfall. But to whom? Some companies say they will share the wealth with workers and communities. But theres less to these claims than meets the eye.

title: Trump Resort in Ireland Gets Approval for Sea Walls
description: DUBLIN  An Irish county council on Thursday gave a golf resort owned by President Trump approval to build two sea walls, a reduced version of an earlier plan but one that still generated opposition from environmentalists.

description: Janet Benshoof, a lawyer who spent much of her career defending a womans right to an abortion, then expanded her work to champion causes for women around the world, including those raped in war zones, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 70.

title: Edward Rowny, Outspoken Treaty Negotiator, Dies at 100
description: Edward L. Rowny, a lieutenant general who advised presidents of both parties during arms control negotiations with the Soviet Union, repeatedly raising warnings about the Russians and arguing that American proposals were too soft, died on Dec. 17 in Washington. He was 100.

title: Fantasy Football: Top Players to Start in N.F.L. Week 16
description: One of the oldest clichs in fantasy football, especially come playoff time, is start your studs, or, similarly, play the guys that got you this far. In general, this is good advice. But as Week 15 proved, its far from foolproof.

description: Roughly two-thirds of the Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar fled this year as soldiers shot them, raped them and torched their homes.

title: Four Days With a Rohingya Family in Exile
description: Ranjuma was nine months pregnant when she and her family escaped violent persecution in Myanmar. They arrived in Bangladesh, where hope turned to tragedy. This is their story.

title: Attorney General Sessions Orders Investigation After Bundy Mistrial
description: Attorney General Jeff Sessions on Thursday ordered an investigation into the high-profile prosecution of anti-government ranchers in Nevada, after a judge declared a mistrial, saying that prosecutors had improperly withheld evidence from the defense.

title: United in Defiance of Trump
description: The United Nations General Assembly voted 128 to 9, with 35 abstentions, for a resolution demanding that the United States rescind its decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israels capital. President Trump threatened to retaliate by cutting aid to countries voting against the U.S.

title: Climate Change Is Driving People From Home. So Why Dont They Count as Refugees?
description: UNITED NATIONS  More than 65 million people are displaced from their homes, the largest number since the Second World War, and nearly 25 million of them are refugees and asylum seekers living outside their own country.

title: In Kyle Kuzma, the Lakers Found a Gem Late in the First Round
description: The N.B.A. invites a curated group of around 20 players to sit in the greenroom at the draft each year. The process cuts down on the number of players who have to sit awkwardly in front of the news media hoping to be picked, but it also leads to roughly a third of the first-round picks not being front and center when Commissioner Adam Silver calls their names.

title: Charles Dutoit, Noted Conductor, Accused of Sexual Assault
description: Several major orchestras announced that they were distancing themselves from the conductor Charles Dutoit, after The Associated Press reported on Thursday that four women claimed that he sexually assaulted them in incidents between 1985 and 2010.

title: Thousands of Federal Inmates Are in the U.S. Illegally, Administration Says
description: About one in five inmates in federal prison are foreign-born, and more than 90 percent of those are in the United States illegally, according to a report released on Thursday by the Trump administration, which has sought to highlight the dangers it says unauthorized immigrants pose to public safety.

title: Ford Apologizes for Sexual Harassment at Chicago Factories
description: Ford Motor Company apologized to its employees on Thursday for sexual harassment at two Chicago plants, addressing accusations that span more than a quarter-century.

title: Tax-Cut Santa Is Coming to Town
description: Its that time of year again. Some of us will get nice gifts, while others will get lumps of coal.

title: Why Do I Give on the Subway?
description: It happens to most of us who live in New York City. Youre on the subway scrolling through a dozen emails, and then you hear the guy coming down through the car (and its usually a guy). Sometimes hes walking, sometimes hes in a wheelchair, navigating between poles and riders feet. Hes rattling a cup of change. The words come haltingly, or not: I hate to bother you, but I need money to get a room tonight, or a meal or something for the kids because there was a fire or flood or financial disaster.

title: For Students Swindled by Predatory Colleges, Relief May Only Be Partial
description: Thousands of students who say they have been swindled by predatory for-profit universities will soon learn whether their loans will be forgiven by the Education Department, but under a new Trump administration policy, some students who expected full loan forgiveness may only receive partial relief.

title: Forget the Strategy Paper. Watch What He Does.
description: Many elements of President Trumps first National Security Strategy report could have been endorsed by his predecessors. The importance of American leadership, a strong defense, a vibrant economy and democratic values  all have a rightful place in the 55-page document made public on Monday.

title: In This Class, Sharing Stories That Once Felt Unspeakable
description: Working out her autobiography to deliver in a class, Mona-Lisa Marrero, 48, tried several beginnings, then settled on: Once upon a time, there was a girl. My name is Mona-Lisa Marrero, and this is my story.

title: The Trump Administration to Restaurants: Take the Tips!
description: Most Americans assume that when they leave a tip for waiters and bartenders, those workers pocket the money. That could become wishful thinking under a Trump administration proposal that would give restaurants and other businesses complete control over the tips earned by their employees.

title: Papa Johns Chief Executive to Step Down, Weeks After Blaming N.F.L. for Sales Slump
description: The pizza franchise Papa Johns announced Thursday that its chief executive, who recently blamed the National Football Leagues handling of the national anthem controversy for the companys declining sales, will step down from the position at the end of the month.

title: Schools Chancellors Legacy: Stories, She Says, Not Statistics
description: Seated next to Mayor Bill de Blasio in the Blue Room at City Hall on Thursday, the retiring schools chancellor, Carmen Faria, 74, offered her own summation of her tenure as the leader of what is in effect a medium-size city, populated by 1.1 million students and 75,000 teachers, and with a $30 billion annual budget.

description: Ed Kranepool insists he is not selling his World Series ring, the one he won during his 18 years with the Mets. Everything else, however, must go.

title: How Memphis Hopes to Move On, Now That Statues Are Down
description: MEMPHIS  Charlene Harmon and her fianc, Victor Bryant, walked Thursday through a small park overlooking the Mississippi River, pleased by the view  and what it did not include.

title: The Hindu Bagpipers of Secaucus
description: In Secaucus, N.J., if you want to hear Queens song We Will Rock You performed by three dozen bagpipers and marching drummers in Scottish kilts, the place to go is the Shree Swaminarayan Temple. Ditto for bagpipe renditions of songs from Bollywood soundtracks or traditional Hindu religious music. The Shree Muktajeevan Swamibapa Pipe Band USA, which formed there in 2003, is a younger sibling to pipe bands in England, Kenya and India, where the tradition goes back to the 1950s.

title: Justice Dept. Revokes 25 Legal Guidance Documents Dating to 1975
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced Thursday that he had revoked more than two dozen documents that interpreted and explained a wide range of federal laws, including guidelines on storing explosives and accommodating people with disabilities.

title: Dispute Over Political Strategy Erupts Inside the White House
description: An Oval Office meeting involving President Trump and his top advisers on Wednesday devolved into a heated exchange between his former campaign manager and the White House political director, people briefed on the discussion said.

title: Trump Administration Considers Separating Families to Combat Illegal Immigration
description: The Trump administration is considering a plan to separate parents from their children when families are caught entering the country illegally, according to officials who have been briefed on the plans. The forceful move is meant to discourage border crossings, but immigrant groups have denounced it as draconian and inhumane.

title: A Former Prison Chef Gets His Own Restaurant
description: Candido Ortiz, a former prison chef while incarcerated for more than 26 years, opened his own restaurant in Jersey City.

title: A Chef Opens a Restaurant. His Training? Decades in a Prison Kitchen.
description: JERSEY CITY  Candido Ortiz claims he can cook anything: mashed potatoes and gravy, pernil guisado, chicken cacciatore. At his new restaurant here, El Sabor del Cafe, he will honor any request.

title: Review: In Father Figures, Ed Helms and Owen Wilson on a Hunt for Dad
description: Moviegoers may recall the basic premise of Father Figures from Flirting With Disaster, a vastly funnier 1996 comedy by David O. Russell. Father Figures doesnt merely flirt. It stars Ed Helms as Peter and Owen Wilson as Kyle, two of the least-related-seeming twins in history. On the day their mother (Glenn Close) marries some cool cat played by Harry Shearer, they learn that their father isnt dead, as they thought, but just unknown. Mom didnt practice monogamy in the disco era.

title: Proposed U.N. Resolution Would Toughen Sanctions on North Korea

description: Sister Diaspora for Liberation, a feminist collective, hosted a self-defense workshop in the Bronx for and by women of color. The class worked to create safe space through sparring, meditation and private dialogue.

title: How to Escape a Burning Building
description: Dont wait until you see smoke or flames, says Margrethe Kobes, a senior researcher at the Institute for Safety in the Netherlands who studies how psychology and building design affect human behavior during fires. For one project, she offered subjects a stay in a four-star hotel. After conducting some sham experiments, everyone went to bed only to be awakened before dawn by a call from the front desk telling them the building was on fire. This, of course, was the real experiment. In a fire, you need to evacuate quickly, but thats not what we see, Kobes says. Instead, people put on their shoes, got dressed, searched for their keys and repeatedly peered out their door into the hallway. Stalling before exiting is what evacuation researchers call the premovement phase. Dont prolong it.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Drinking Straight From the Carton
description: Alec writes: My significant other of many years drinks directly from the milk carton. This is very, very gross. Particularly disturbing, she has no issues then offering our soiled milk to unsuspecting guests. I seek an injunction plus damages in the form of back rubs for the emotional trauma that I have suffered.

description: RE: FIRST WORDS

title: Poem: Ligament
description: Ever wonder about the role a sentence can play in a poem? It can be more controlled and malleable than a prose sentence. It can be a bit more subtle than a line break. The elegant sentence in this poem ties, sews and flows in a stream of chemical consciousness. The anaphoric even, the visceral sounds stitched into the syntax, the intimacy of the ending: It requires breath to read. It prompts a gasp.

title: In Philadelphia, a Comic Book Store Dedicated to Diversity
description: In the historically working-class Kensington neighborhood of Philadelphia, just a few minutes northeast of landmarks like Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell, a unique literary destination has blossomed. Amalgam Comics & Coffeehouse, which has become a popular draw since its opening in December 2015, is the brainchild of Ariell R. Johnson, a Baltimore native and alumna of nearby Temple University. Ms. Johnson, one of the first African-American female owners of a comic book store on the East Coast, has infused a cultural dynamism into the city and a sense of inclusiveness within her store. She has been featured on the cover of Marvels Invincible Iron Man #1, and was recently awarded a $50,000 grant by the Knight Foundation for an expansion.

title: Harriet Tubmans Hymnal
description: In 2010, a church hymnal that once belonged to Harriet Tubman  the American abolitionist hero who, after escaping slavery in 1849, devoted her new freedom to leading hundreds more of her fellow enslaved out of captivity, first as a conductor on the underground railroad and then later as a Union spy  was donated to the National Museum of African American History and Culture by the collector and historian Charles L. Blockson. Given to him by Tubmans great-grandniece Mariline Wilkins (the daughter of Eva Stewart Northrup, whose signature is inscribed inside the books cover), it was just one of dozens of Tubmans belongings bequeathed to the museum that day. Eric Williams, the curator of religion at the Smithsonians Center for the Study of African American Religious Life, considers the book particularly revelatory, given that Tubman was illiterate. This idea of having a sacred book and not being able to read it, he said in a phone interview, thats a window into her piety. And it is in line with a longer tradition one finds in the black religious experience in North America. Although many black men and women, whether enslaved or free, could not read them, he explained, these books  the Bible and hymnals  bore witness to the liberating power of the Gospel contained within their pages. Williams told me that for Tubman, who could sing every word it contains, this hymnal would have been invested with a spiritual power, and that it is a text to be valued not just as literature but as artifact  as an object of devotion.

title: Greater Access to Donated Livers Promised to Transplant Patients
description: With Manhattan skyscrapers as a backdrop, Roscoe and Sharon Fawcett celebrated their 29th anniversary with a meal of steak, corn and baked potatoes.

title: Bed, Board and Beyond: Hotels Venture Into Entertainment
description: Based on a wave of new hotel amenities, ranging from bowling alleys to theaters, the future of hospitality looks a lot like the past when hotels were social hubs. Competitive forces and a basic business drive to boost revenue are producing a new class of hotels with entertainment features that go beyond the celebrity chef-run restaurant in the lobby.

description: THE EXODUS By Richard Elliott Friedman 282 pp. HarperOne. $27.99.

title: For One Rohingya Family, I Hoped for Redemption. That Hope Was Dashed.
description: NAYAPARA REFUGEE CAMP, Bangladesh  A truck trying to overtake another car darted out from the wrong side of the road and slammed into the rickshaw. The tiny vehicle crumpled like a piece of tin foil, flipped twice and finally settled bottom upward. The truck that hit it sped away. For a moment, the six members of Nor Hossains family, who had been riding inside, lay upside down in silence, covered in dirt, battery fluids and blood. It was their second day in Bangladesh.

description: CRIMES OF THE FATHER By Thomas Keneally 334 pp. Atria. $26.

description: Jonathan Traub was supposed to spend his family vacation in Breckenridge, Colo., skiing and roasting marshmallows.

title: In Brooklyn, a Hare Krishna Reckoning
description: Weekdays at Govindas Vegetarian Lunch, a cafeteria in the basement of Sri Sri Radha Govinda Mandir, the Hare Krishna temple located in the rapidly developing area of Downtown Brooklyn, is a peaceful affair. Outside, there are cranes, scaffolding and cement trucks. But inside and down a few stairs, there is faint, dulcet chanting piped through speakers. Contented diners, ranging from municipal workers to financial sector employees, sit together with plates piled full of eggplant Parmesan and chana masala.

title: Brokers Who Go Big With Their Closing Gifts
description: Last spring, when J.J. Hill finally closed on his dream apartment  a light-filled loft in TriBeCa  the only thing missing was someone (or something) with whom to share it.

title: Trump Promised to Protect Steel. Layoffs Are Coming Instead.
description: CONSHOHOCKEN, Pa.  At this sprawling steel mill on the outskirts of Philadelphia, the workers have one number in mind. Not how many tons of steel roll off the line, or how many hours they work, but where they fall on the plants seniority list.

title: What Acts of Bravery Have You Witnessed This Year?
description: In your opinion, what makes someone a hero?

title: Carols by a Cellphones Glow: See How Puerto Rico Is Celebrating Christmas
description: A group of friends in Guaynabo, P.R., were singing by the light of their cellphones.

title: Their Words to Live By: Artists We Lost in 2017
description: Artists who died this year left behind gripping scenes, profound turns of phrase, unforgettable melodies and plenty of laughter. We pay tribute to a few of the most notable  through their own words.

title: Seth Meyers Calls Out Trump for Saying He Repealed Obamacare
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: Jerusalem, Dick Enberg, Jumanji: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Visiting Afghanistan, Pence Says U.S. Will See This Through
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Vice President Mike Pence, making an unannounced trip to Afghanistan, reaffirmed the Trump administrations support for the countrys beleaguered government and starkly warned neighboring Pakistan to stop harboring militant groups that have long undermined the United States-led coalitions mission here.

title: Fifty Shades of Orange
description: At a televised cabinet meeting on Wednesday, Donald Trump, as is his custom, called on his appointees to publicly praise him. In a performance that would have embarrassed the most obsequious lackey of the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, Vice President Mike Pence delivered an encomium to his boss, who sat across the table with arms folded over his chest, absorbing abasement as his due.

title: Comeback Words for 2018
description: You can call a slimehead by the better-known name of orange roughy, but its still an ugly fish. The same goes for President Trumps attempt to euphemize a first year in office that was historic for all the wrong reasons.

title: Cardinal Tobin, Am I a Christian?
description: What is Christmas about, anyway? Can I be a Christian if I doubt the virgin birth? Can a woman become a cardinal? What would upset Jesus today? I put these blunt questions and more to Cardinal Joseph Tobin of Newark, who was appointed by Pope Francis and is in his mold. Heres our conversation, edited for space and clarity.

title: Should We Forgive the Men Who Assaulted Us?
description: Fourteen months ago, long before #MeToo spawned a movement, I wrote an essay for the Los Angeles Jewish Journal about a disturbing encounter I had with a high-profile Israeli journalist and author.

title: If This Is America
description: If this is America, with a cabinet of terrorized toadies genuflecting to the Great Leader, a vice president offering a compliment every 12 seconds to Mussolinis understudy, and a White House that believes in alternative facts, then it is time to keep your head when all about you are losing theirs.

title: Special Episode: The Year in Sound
description: An audio time capsule of 2017. From inauguration to the tax bill  and the hurricanes, shootings and scandals in between.

title: The Year in Sound: An Audio Time Capsule of 2017
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: Sundays at the Altar of Science
description: I think its sad that you feel like youre alone in the universe, my mom recently said to me.

title: New York Today: Alone in an Empty City
description: Good morning on this fickle Friday.

title: Is It Better to Cook With Coconut Oil or Olive Oil?
description: Q. Is it better to cook with coconut oil or olive oil?

title: In Search of Lost Time
description: Memoirists can struggle with the why should anyone care? question even in the dullest of times. But in a year when it seemed there was only enough bandwidth for the latest crisis out of Washington, publishing a book about the contents of ones own memory probably felt like an especially daunting proposition.

title: Feeding Houstonians With a Feast From a Wedding Disrupted
description: Rain on your wedding day is said to be good luck, but how much does the trick? Danya Skolkin and Josh Tillis didnt pause to consider the ratio of precipitation to luck when skies turned ominous in the days just before their wedding last fall.

title: Life, Death and Taxes in Inequality City
description: Among many other indignities, the $1.5 trillion tax plan pushed through Congress this week, as others have pointed out, unleashes a special enmity at coastal cities and the Soul Cycle- and science-loving people who live in them. To the extent that tax cuts for the extraordinarily wealthy function as a means to push further measures of austerity  to provide the excuse to reduce federal funding for social programs on which cities rely  we can anticipate ever-escalating rates of inequality in places like New York, where the divisions between rich and poor are already severe. During the coming weeks and months, accountants and policy analysts will be kept very busy trying to parse the specific impact of the new tax code on individuals, families, institutions and markets of different kinds.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Ice Cream, Tea and Families
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Leontyne Price, Legendary Diva, Is a Movie Star at 90
description: COLUMBIA, Md.  The soprano Leontyne Price, who retired from singing 20 years ago, assumed that the triumphs of her illustrious career were behind her. Not so. At 90, Ms. Price has become an unlikely movie star.

title: How Latham Thomas, Wellness Guru, Spends Her Sundays
description: As the founder of Mama Glow, a wellness resource for both expecting and new mothers, Latham Thomas has made a career out of teaching self-care to women all over the world. Sunday is when she practices what she preaches. I want to be with my son and fianc and show myself some love, she said. Ms. Thomas, 37, lives in Chelsea with Thomas Rasmussen, 55, who works in finance, and her 14-year-old son, Fulano Librizzi, who is a D.J.

title: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
description: Theres a reason George Balanchine, City Ballets legendary founder, gets title billing in this version of the holiday tradition: It very much bears his unique blend of sophistication and joy. Of the many productions of this tale in town, George Balanchines The Nutcracker, now through Dec. 31, is most likely to satisfy adults with its visual splendor and breathtaking dance. The children, of course, will cheer the lively characters, colorful costumes and that gargantuan magical tree. This week, 10 stellar ballerinas trade off in the showcase role of the Sugarplum, from elegant, established principles like Sterling Hyltin (Dec. 23 evening) and Sara Mearns (Dec. 26 evening) to exciting new soloists like Unity Phelan (Dec. 22 evening, Dec. 27 matinee) and Emilie Gerrity (Dec. 26 matinee). BRIAN SCHAEFER

title: One of Bitcoins Biggest Champions Turns Bearish: DealBook Briefing
description: Good Friday. Heres what were watching:

title: Christmas in the I.C.U.
description: The plastic chairs creak as we sit. I wipe a few crumbs off the table and watch them fall to the floor as I prepare to tell my patients adult son what I suspect he knows already but doesnt want to hear: After weeks in the intensive care unit, his mothers organs are failing and shell never wake up or breathe on her own again.

title: Your Week in Culture: Black Mirror, Monteverdi, The Hip Hop Nutcracker
description: New TV shows, museum openings, film releases and concerts  its a lot to keep track of. Let us help you. For the week of Dec. 24, seven events in New York and elsewhere not to be missed:

title: Ryanair Hit With Its First Pilot Strike, in Germany
description: Ryanair was hit by the first strike in its company history on Friday after pilots in Germany staged a four-hour walkout, days after the airline agreed to recognize unions but talks fell apart.

title: How (Not) to Break an Election Tie
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

title: The Best Rooms Featured in T in 2017
description: From a Los Angeles loft to an Italian castle, highlights from the interiors we featured in the last year.

title: The Best Rooms in T in 2017
description: From a tiny Fire Island kit house, to an all-gray apartment in Copenhagen to a neo-Classical home in Milan, T has featured a wide range of stunning, one-of-a-kind homes this year. Click through our slide show for some of the best rooms we featured in 2017.

title: Pop Music in 2017: Glum and Glummer
description: Push me to the edge/All my friends are dead, Lil Uzi Vert intones in XO TOUR Llif3, at first in a matter-of-fact chant and later in a slurred, raw singsong. The backing track is a bass line going nowhere slowly, oozing to bind together twitches of electronic percussion and little tinkles and twangs that drift in and out. The lyrics, rapped and sung in an assortment of scratchy voices, juggle the bitterness of a crumbling relationship alongside career boasts and druggy, suicidal ramblings.

title: Chairman of Lotte Group Is Convicted of Graft in South Korea, but Avoids Jail
description: A court in Seoul, South Korea, on Friday convicted Shin Dong-bin, the chairman of the multinational Lotte Group, of embezzlement and breach of trust in connection with a corruption scandal, according to the Yonhap news agency.

title: Should You Shower in the Morning, or at Night? Yes
description: There were few greater sins in my childhood home than going to bed dirty, though I could sometimes appease my mother by just washing my feet before slipping between the clean sheets. Now, as an adult, I cannot bear to get in bed with the grime of the day clinging to my skin. And Im not alone.

title: Farhad and Mikes Week in Tech: Cuckoo for Cryptocurrency
description: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

title: The Women Who Run the Star Wars Universe
description: Princess Leia is tough, idealistic and frequently sardonic. Yet she is also quiet. Women in the original Star Wars trilogy spoke fewer than half as many words as their male colleagues did. Leias limited dialogue in Star Wars went unchallenged in 1977, but 40 years later, the lack of meaty roles for women and people of color in Hollywood is under new scrutiny. While those in the film industry ponder how to better reflect the diversity of human experience in their scripts, at Lucasfilm, a small group of women and men may have found one answer.

title: Do Security Systems Make Your Home Safer?
description: After my sisters house was broken into and burglarized last summer, I decided to get a home alarm. You would think that I would have had one already  buy a house and one of the first things your broker (or your mother) tells you to do is to secure the place.

title: You Asked, Ron Lieber Answered: How Will This Tax Bill Affect You?
description: The Reader Center is one way we in the newsroom are trying to connect with you, by highlighting your perspectives and experiences and offering insight into how we work.

title: California Today: Should Shelter Dogs Be Vegan?
description: Good morning. California Today will take a break for the Christmas holiday. Well be back on Tuesday.

title: Stop Trying to Make Youthquake Happen: Readers Pick Their Words of the Year
description: The announcement that Oxford Dictionaries had chosen youthquake as its international Word of the Year, triumphing over a shortlist that also included white fragility, kompromat and Antifa, drew puzzlement across the English-speaking world.

title: Did Rome Kill Its Christmas Tree?
description: ROME  If the paragon of all Christmas trees is the one in front of the Rockefeller Center in New York  first erected, mind you, by an Italian in 1931  the prize for most pitiful must go to the one that stands in Romes Piazza Venezia this year. Just days after it was put up, it began to gray and shed its needles, and soon it had become nearly see-through. The tree cuts so sad and forlorn a figure that it has been nicknamed Spelacchio, or Mangy.

title: Meghan Markles Sheer Top Was a Sneaky Statement for a Royal Portrait
description: Meghan Markle, the soon-to-be wife of the man who is soon to be sixth in line to the British throne, set off something of a controversy this week when the couples official engagement photographs were released.

title: It Was a Year of Mind-Boggling Prices, but Art Is in a Funny Place
description: LONDON  Viewed from the top, 2017 has been a momentous year for the art market. After a Jean-Michel Basquiat sold for $110.5 million at auction in May, and a Leonardo da Vinci soared to $450.3 million last month, paintings by world-famous artists have never looked more expensive. But will the increasingly high prices paid for such trophies have a trickle-down effect on the rest of the art world?

title: Pandoro Is Italys Christmas Miracle. Easter Is Another Story.
description: VERONA, Italy  Elena Galeotto, a longtime employee of Melegatti, Italys original producer of traditional pandoro Christmas cakes, scooped this seasons final mound of dough from the conveyor belt, rounded it and dropped it into a deep, star-shaped cast.

title: The Best Poetry of 2017
description: The end of 2017 is a good time to reflect on the surprising fact that the past year was not all a dream. We do indeed live in a world in which President of the United States Donald John Trump routinely misuses quotation marks while conducting foreign policy on Twitter; we really have heard the last from Chuck Berry; and it is actually the case that a large number of powerful men appear to have been laboring for years under the impression that the American workplace was pants-optional. Given this reality, why not read some poems? It cant hurt.

title: Diane Kruger Returns Home and Wins Big
description: Who says you cant go home again? Twenty-five years after departing her native Germany to model in Paris, Diane Kruger is finally starring in her first German-language movie  a role for which she won best actress at the Cannes Film Festival in May.

title: Elusive Vampire Film Steps Out of the Shadows
description: Vampir Cuadecuc is a ghostly film as well as the ghost of a film and perhaps the ghost of cinema itself.

title: The First Lady of the Canadiens Sits Behind the Montreal Bench
description: MONTREAL  Hours before the puck drops at Bell Centre, lise Bliveau can be found in the Salon des Anciens Canadiens. She converses with family and friends, sharing laughs and stories of yesteryear in a room where walls are decorated with framed photographs of her husband, Jean Bliveau, who won 10 Stanley Cups as a Canadiens player and seven more as a team executive.

title: Bitcoin Plummets More Than 30 Percent in Less Than a Day
description: You cant exactly say that Bitcoin was burning a hole in anyones pocket, but the virtual currency burned a hole in quite a few hearts on Friday when it plunged 30 percent in less than 24 hours after defying gravity for the past few months.

title: An Israeli Settler, a Dead Palestinian and the Crux of the Conflict
description: QUSRA, West Bank  It started as a bar mitzvah hike through rocky, biblical terrain. It ended with a Palestinian man shot dead and 20 traumatized Israeli schoolchildren sheltering in a cave from Palestinian stone-throwers.

title: Trump Could Save More Than $11 Million Under the New Tax Plan
description: A Times analysis of his only publicly available tax return found that his tax bill would be about 30 percent less.

title: Watch These Brooklyn Skate Club Regulars Dance Their Wheels Off
description: Wheels on wood. That soothing sound is a giveaway  the gymnasium at the Salvation Army Bedford Day Care Center in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, isnt a sad, decaying space cheered up with Christmas lights and a disco ball. This gleaming setting is home to Brooklyn Skate Club, a weekly tonic for the soul.

title: Phoebe Philo Exits Cline, Adding to Fashion Turmoil
description: A decade after transforming Cline into the favored label of power women everywhere and beginning a new era of minimalism in fashion, Phoebe Philo, its artistic director, has announced she is leaving the house.

title: Feeling Blue (and Feeling Good): U.K. Picks a Post-Brexit Passport Color
description: LONDON  Britains journey into Brexit has been a little bumpy. Banking jobs are in peril, and doctors and nurses are heading back across the English Channel. Employers are struggling to find workers. Negotiations with the European Union on the British departure have been fractious.

title: If You Want to Know How the New Tax Code Affects You, Read This First
description: If youre struggling to figure out exactly how the tax overhaul will affect you, youve come to right place. Here is a brief overview of the new provisions, and what it means for your returns.

title: For Hunters in the Woods, a Quiet Killer: Tree Stands
description: Jeff Callahan can still recall the morning he dozed off while hunting deer from a homemade tree-stand in upstate New York.

title: In Signing Sweeping Tax Bill, Trump Questions Whether He Is Getting Enough Credit
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump signed the most consequential tax legislation in three decades on Friday, even as he complained that he has not been given credit for his administrations accomplishments during a turbulent first year.

title: What Happens When the Richest U.S. Cities Turn to the World?
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Well before anyone thought of this place as the center of the tech economy, the Bay Area built ships. And it did so with the help of many parts of the country.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

title: Readers React to Glenn Thrushs Punishment; We Respond
description: The Reader Center is one way we in the newsroom are trying to connect with you, by highlighting your perspectives and experiences and offering insight into how we work.

title: For Travelers to Ireland, Luggage Tags Make Statement on Abortion
description: LONDON  As travelers board flights to Ireland and Northern Ireland for the Christmas holiday, they are finding themselves in the company of fliers toting a message on their luggage tags about the journey women on the island must make to have an abortion.

title: New York, New York, a Wonderful Drinking Town
description: This fat 352-page book covers drinking in New York from every angle, justifying the notion that this is the epicenter of the cocktail world. Youll find the classics, pre- and post-Prohibition trends, significant personalities in the drinks world and profiles of bars and lounges and their signature cocktails. The recipes for holidays include a cosmopolitan, made not with cranberry juice but shaken with cranberry sauce and strained: New York Cocktails: An Elegant Collection of Over 100 Recipes Inspired by the Big Apple, by Amanda Schuster (Cider Mill Press, $19.95).

title: A Small Gem for an Intimate Dinner
description: Anne Saxelby considers St. Johnsville Jr. soft-ripening goat cheese as a paragon of subtle elegance. It has a somewhat rumpled, downy white rind. The six-ounce disk of cheese, about three inches across, has a chalky center that turns to satin when fully ripe. The aroma is herbal, and the flavor is mild and fresh with a hint of musk: St. Johnsville Jr. goat cheese, Cochran Farm 1790, St. Johnsville, N.Y.; $13 for six ounces at Saxelby Cheese in the Essex Street and Chelsea markets, saxelbycheese.com.

title: Searching for the (Star) Light at the Vatican Observatory
description: ALBANO LAZIALE, Italy  Some 2,000 years ago, a celestial phenomenon is believed to have lit up the sky. Guiding the wise men of New Testament lore to the birthplace of Jesus, the star of Bethlehem has since become a planetarium and Christmas carol favorite.

title: Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer
description: The Gene Autry standard

title: Malaysian Leader Says Worlds Muslims Should Not Lose to the Jews
description: BANGKOK  A protest in Malaysia against President Trumps decision to designate Jerusalem the capital of Israel brought together political foes on Friday, illustrating how solidarity with Palestinians has united disparate forces in the Muslim world.

title: Salmon Fit for a Czar
description: Among the iterations of smoked and cured fish sold by Petrossian is a versatile new triple-smoked salmon. Prepared this way, their thick Tsar-Cut salmon is exceptionally meaty but still succulent, with a delicate salinity. The salmon can be sliced thin for canaps on toast or dark bread and served with Champagne to ring in the new, slivered to toss with buttered pasta or savored in scrambled eggs for that 2018 brunch: Petrossian Souho-style Tsar-Cut smoked salmon, $60 for a four-ounce slab, petrossian.com.

title: Dont Despair, Protest: Playwright Lucy Kirkwood Sees No Other Choice
description: The British playwright Lucy Kirkwood gets the jitters on opening nights, and it was no different earlier this month when she made her Broadway debut with The Children. But at the post-show party, at a blues club near Times Square, politics proved an unexpectedly pleasant distraction.

title: The #MeToo Moment: What Happened After Women Broke the Silence Elsewhere?
description: As the sexual misconduct scandals continue to unfold, our gender team is providing updates and analysis on the coverage and conversation. Today, Somini Sengupta, a longtime international correspondent, looks at other countries public reckonings with sexual misconduct.

title: A Citrus Press With More Torque
description: This new juicer for lemons and limes provides more leverage than most typical hand-held citrus presses. Instead of downward pressure, you set the fruit cut side down in the stainless steel container, match the dots as you insert the top and then pull the handles together. Pits stay in the container: Joseph Joseph Helix citrus juicer, $20, josephjoseph.com/en-us.

title: Onions Without the Tears
description: The color is as bright as ever in this new sweet red onion grown in the Netherlands, but the typical bold pungency is absent. Slice them with abandon into salads and sandwiches, chop them to top a bowl of soup or tacos, or mince them for ceviche, all without shedding a tear. Theyre excellent to grill: Gourmet USA sweet red onions, $1.99 a pound, Fairway Markets.

title: How Disaster Charity Can Pivot to Sustainable Philanthropy
description: This has been a heavy year of natural disasters: Hurricanes Harvey, Irma and Maria, wildfires in California, the Mexico City earthquake, a monsoon in Bangladesh.

title: The Peril of Taxing Elite Higher Education
description: The tax legislation approved this week by Congress is a mixed bag. It combines some badly needed reforms with various messy provisions seemingly designed to keep accountants and tax lawyers fully employed. But the part of the bill that most disappoints me is a small, simple change in policy: a new tax on large university endowments.

title: The Sandwich Game Is Strong in Brooklyn
description: Gordon Savory, a compact shop in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, is well stocked with tins of imported Spanish sardines, wedges of Reading raclette (an American version of the Swiss classic), condiments from Brooklyn Delhi and fresh croissants and baguettes. Anna Gordon and Steven Hartong, who own the Good Batch bakery across the street, opened the shop. Jason Rivera, a former sous-chef at Charlie Bird, makes artful sandwiches and salads, many of them featuring eggs boiled in that sweet spot between soft- and hard-cooked. Roast chicken and meatballs in sauce are sold to take home. There are a few counter stools near the window: Gordon Savory, 995a Fulton Street (St. James Place), Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, 347-889-5696; gordonsavory.com.

title: Flying Abandoned Animals to Safer Havens
description: Kara Pollard, 33, is the executive director of Dog Is My CoPilot, an animal rescue operation in Jackson, Wyo.

title: The Story of the Jews Continues
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: A Review of Year-End Reviews: The Canada Letter
description: Ritual certainly plays a role in the various year-end items that The Times and other news organizations unfailingly push out every December. And when I worked at a weekly newsmagazine, they provided a way for the staff to take a break.

title: The Playlist: Cardi B Isnt Going Anywhere and 9 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. This week, Sugarland returns with its first song in seven years, Charli XCX teams with Carly Rae Jepsen and Laura Marling covers a Bob Dylan classic.

title: A Sex Pistols Concert Film Languished for Four Decades. Heres Why.
description: Forty years ago next month, the Sex Pistols started their first tour of the United States. It was also, famously, their last. After seven electrifying, antagonistic performances, the band broke up.

title: Forbidden Words: Censorship at the C.D.C.?
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N.s Rebuke of Trump on Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: With Trump in the White House, the Family Business Takes It Down a Notch
description: CLEVELAND, Miss.  Storage trailers, an idle dump truck and portable toilets surround the hotel construction site. A sign announces opening fall 2017, but residents say they havent seen significant activity for months.

title: Trump Watches News. Rushes to Sign Tax Bill.
description: President Trump pushed aside a formal signing in January to sign the tax legislation because television news networks questioned whether he would keep his promise to sign the legislation before Christmas.

title: Super Yayas Rym Beydoun Sees the Future of Fashion
description: Name Rym Beydoun

title: When William Styron Ruled the Best-Seller List
description: HAPPY OLD YEAR: Half a century ago, in the winter after the Summer of Love, American reading habits were as turbulent as the culture at large. William Styrons novel of slave rebellion, The Confessions of Nat Turner, ruled the fiction best-seller list of Dec. 31, 1967, where it was joined by titles as varied as The Exhibitionist (Henry Suttons sex-soaked Hollywood romp), The Chosen (Chaim Potoks coming-of-age tale about Jewish identity) and The Presidents Plane Is Missing (Robert J. Serlings political thriller about a constitutional crisis). And  in maybe the clearest sign that you would have needed the Richter scale to measure the zeitgeist of the late 1960s  the same list made room for both Christy, Catherine Marshalls historical Christian romance, and Rosemarys Baby, Ira Levins tale of satanic horror. Strange days, as the Doors noted that fall.

title: WNYC Chief Pushed Growth at the Cost of Stations Culture
description: When Laura R. Walker, the president and chief executive of New York Public Radio, addressed the crowd at an open WNYC board meeting last week, she said she was profoundly pained and sorry about managements handling of alleged inappropriate conduct by several on-air stars.

title: Seven Years After His Dismissal, Omar Minaya Is Back With the Mets
description: In an unusual move to beef up their front office, the Mets have reunited with Omar Minaya, whom they dismissed as their general manager seven years ago.

title: Taylor Swifts Rivals This Holiday: Bing Crosby and Nat King Cole
description: It wasnt so long ago that a blockbuster fourth-quarter album by a music superstar could rescue a record company from financial ruin, or at least a slow sales year. Think of Jay-Zs Kingdom Come, which sold 680,000 copies during Black Friday week in 2006 and showed up beneath plenty of Christmas trees that year.

title: 2 Top Soccer Officials Found Guilty in FIFA Case
description: Two top international soccer officials were found guilty on Friday for their roles in a web of corruption that extended across several continents and ensnared dozens of men who control the worlds most popular sport.

title: Sublime Leontyne: The 8 Best Classical Music Moments of the Week on YouTube
description: Our critics and reporters offer a glimpse of whats moved and delighted them on YouTube. Read the rest of our classical music coverage here.

title: Security Council Tightens Economic Vise on North Korea, Blocking Fuel, Ships and Workers
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations Security Council placed new sanctions on North Korea on Friday that significantly choke off fuel supplies and order North Koreans working overseas to return home, in what may prove the last test of whether any amount of economic pressure can force the isolated country to reverse course on its nuclear weapons program.

title: Prosecutors Said to Seek Kushner Records From Deutsche Bank
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn have sought bank records about entities associated with the family company of Jared Kushner, President Trumps son-in-law and senior adviser, according to four people briefed on the matter.

title: Glitter Bombs, Past Lives and Ovary Tattoos at Busts Craftacular
description: As snow fell on the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn in mid-December, a dozen or so people gathered inside a room at the Brooklyn Expo Center to uncover the truth about their past lives. Seated on folding chairs around a large red rug, they closed their eyes and followed the teachers instructions to imagine themselves stepping through a door connected to their bedroom and into their former selves.

title: Gun Violence and Human Rights
description: Benefits were held for Sandy Hook Promise, Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights, Museum of the Moving Image and Acria.

title: Dick Enberg, Veteran Sportscaster, Is Dead at 82
description: Dick Enberg, the sportscaster known for his warm voice and signature expression, Oh, my! when beholding a game-winning home run or a brilliant volley at Wimbledon, died on Thursday at his home in the San Diego enclave of La Jolla. He was 82.

title: Resuming Camera Uploads With Dropbox
description: Q. I had my iPhone and iPad set up to send all my photos to my Dropbox account, so I could access them on my PC. Suddenly, about six weeks ago, they no longer do this and I cant figure out how to reset it so they will. It is possible that I told my iPhone to send my photos to the iCloud library on that day, but I dont remember for sure. Please help!

title: U.S. Government Went Through These Peoples Phones at the Border. Read Their Stories.
description: WASHINGTON  A newly disclosed trove of about 250 complaints filed by people whose cellphones, laptops, tablets and other personal electronics were searched by border agents without a warrant as they entered the United States is shedding light on a growing debate over individual privacy, collective security and 21st-century technology.

title: Sprawling Across New York, a Solstice Music Marathon
description: The winter solstice sometimes brings damp and bitter cold, so Make Music Winter, the explosion of mostly participatory, mostly al fresco musical parades held throughout New York City each Dec. 21, can be hit or miss. But this Thursday was gorgeous  crisp and sunny  making it a pleasure for our critics and reporters to fan out to some of this years offerings. ZACHARY WOOLFE

title: Privacy Complaints Mount Over Phone Searches at U.S. Border Since 2011
description: WASHINGTON  They spoke of being humiliated and shaken. They described being made to feel like a criminal. And they maintained that their rights had been violated.

title: Read Complaints About Warrantless Searches of Electronic Devices at the U.S. Border
description: The Department of Homeland Security, in response to a Freedom of Information Act request, has released several hundred complaints filed since 2011 by people whose phones, laptops or other electronic devices were searched without a warrant at the United States border as they entered the country.

title: The Year in France: Coverage From The New York Times in 2017
description: PARIS  In Paris, it is always possible to wander into the past. But this year, it was also possible to glimpse the future.

title: Past Debates Echo in Split Between Cornel West and Ta-Nehisi Coates
description: For more coverage of race, sign up here to have our Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.

title: Tales of the Cocktail, a Troubled Event, May Have a Savior
description: Tales of the Cocktail, the annual New Orleans convention that over the last 15 years has became a required whistle stop for people in the bar and spirits business, has recently been in danger of dissolution amid rancor and controversy.

title: Monkey Bread
description: Learn how to make this delicious tear-apart treat.

title: A Pull-Apart Bread Worth Sharing (Even if You Dont Want to)
description: Since no one ever seems to invite me to a pig pull or a crab boil, I miss eating communally. I dont mean sitting at a communal table in a restaurant, staring down strangers while we all nibble at our seasonal small plates. I mean everyone digging into the same dish at the same time. I mean the warm feeling I get sharing French fondue or Korean barbecue.

title: Trump Promised to Kill Carried Interest. Lobbyists Kept it Alive.
description: WASHINGTON  President Trumps signature on the Republican tax bill marks his most important legislative achievement to date. It also represents the breaking of a signature promise that helped propel his populist presidential campaign.

title: A Slap in the Face: Pick of White Man to Lead Council Draws Fire
description: For months, black political leaders watched the bare-knuckled, back-room race to lead the New York City Council with a mix of hope and trepidation. Five of the eight candidates were black or Hispanic  offering the prospect of a first black speaker  but two of the most prominent front-runners were white men.

title: How to Resist Office Gift-Fund Pressure
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: A Teenager Said She Had Been Raped in Her Home Country. The U.S. Opposed Her Abortion.
description: The 17-year-old migrant was pregnant. She said she had been raped in her home county, and she knew from the timing that she was carrying her attackers child.

title: In Old Borscht Belt, New Casino Brings a Glimmer of Hope
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y.  Sherelle Baker was spending more money on gas driving to work from her home here than she made at the job as a waitress-bartender. Then her hours got cut.

title: An Illuminated Hebrew Bible Has a New Home
description: On Wednesday, the final day of Hanukkah, the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced its acquisition of an illuminated Hebrew Bible from 14th-century Spain.

title: A Sports Titans Strange and Sudden Abdication
description: As president of ESPN, John Skipper was among the most important people in sports. He dropped billions of dollars on professional leagues and college conferences to broadcast their games. He dictated when and how we watched and talked about them.

title: Marijuana for Christmas? Elderly Couple Arrested With 60 Pounds for Gifts
description: A couple in their 80s were arrested in Nebraska on Tuesday for allegedly transporting 60 pounds of marijuana, worth several hundred thousand dollars, which they told the police they intended to give away as Christmas presents.

title: Somewhere Between a Food Truck and a Food Tent, Youll Find a Cubert
description: Elizabeth Mirandas food dream centers on churros, and her goal someday is to have a brick-and-mortar bakery where she can sell them along with her reimagined versions of other traditional Mexican pastries. For now, she settles for a stall at one of San Franciscos outdoor markets.

title: F.B.I. Director Wants to Move Forward, but the President Is Making His Job Harder
description: WASHINGTON  When President Trump tapped Christopher A. Wray to be his next F.B.I. director, it signaled a clear break from the tenure of James B. Comey, whom Mr. Trump had grown to distrust and eventually fired.

title: U.S. Tax Bill May Inspire Cuts Globally, While Fueling Trade Tensions
description: To President Trump and congressional Republicans, the overhaul of the tax code that became law on Friday will make the United States a better place to do business. To the rest of the world, it has the potential to challenge the global economic order, creating an uneven playing field and setting off a race among countries to cut corporate taxes.

title: Homeless Group Honors the Dead, and Celebrates Victories
description: As they have every December for the last for 17 years, members of the Picture the Homeless group gathered on Thursday night at a Manhattan church to remember friends and strangers who died over the past year without a permanent place to live.

title: What Were Reading
description: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What Were Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

title: Four Senators Seek Longer Foreclosure Delay in Puerto Rico
description: A bipartisan group of United States senators wants federal housing agencies to extend a moratorium on foreclosures in Puerto Rico into 2019 after the devastation on the island and a big surge in mortgage delinquencies.

title: How Billy Crudup Plays 19 People in a One-Man Show
description: Billy Crudup explains how he becomes 19 characters in David Cales play Harry Clarke, which follows a shy Midwesterner as he reinvents himself as a Cockney Englishman.

title: Catalonias Election Yields a Crisis That Is Here to Stay
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Since taking charge of Spain six years ago, Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy has done his best to remain aloof from the gathering threat of secessionism in Catalonia.

title: Miss America Leaders Resign Amid Scandal Over Derogatory Emails
description: Three executives of the Miss America Organization resigned on Saturday after reports that the pageants leadership had attacked and derided former pageant winners in emails.

title: Holiday Fiction, Just in Time for Christmas
description: Youre sure to get a healthy dose of holiday movies and shows on your screens, but if you prefer literary escapes, here are recent holiday books to get you in the spirit.

title: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
description: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: The Barca Way Spreads Far From Catalonia
description: Everywhere you look, the fingerprints are visible. They are there in those places where the lights shine brightest, and they are there where the lights dont shine at all.

title: Trump, North Korea, Star Wars: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Woman, Around 80, Accused of Smuggling Cocaine Into Beirut Airport
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A woman who is around 80 was arrested at Beiruts international airport on Friday after trying to smuggle about 68 pounds of cocaine, according to government officials and state media in Lebanon, which called the illicit operation the largest in recent memory.

title: Fiat Chrysler to Recall 1.8 Million Ram Trucks Over Rollaways
description: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles said on Friday that it planned to recall about 1.8 million Ram pickup trucks that could be shifted out of park without the drivers foot on the brake.

title: Will Eminem Ever Change?
description: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

title: Acts of Resistance and Restraint Defy Easy Definition in the West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  It is quite a video: A teenage girl, a kaffiyeh over her denim jacket, screaming in Arabic, repeatedly punches, slaps and kicks a heavily armed Israeli army officer, who faces her impassively, absorbing some blows, evading others, but never hitting back.

title: With Cuomo Assist, Homeowners Rush to Soften Tax Bills Impact
description: Every time he stepped away from his desk last week, the supervisor of the Town of Greenburgh returned to a voice mail message from a resident wanting to know if it was possible to prepay at least a portion of the 2018 property tax bill in the waning days of 2017.

title: Tax Bill Hysteria
description: In case you havent heard, nearly all thats good and pleasant in the world died this week. The tax bill passed.

title: Book Your Calendar
Dr. Kings Interconnected World
description: Fifty years ago Sunday  Christmas Eve 1967  the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. stood in his pulpit at Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta and told the congregation that in order to achieve peace on earth, we must develop a world perspective, a vision for the entire planet. Yes, he said, as nations and individuals, we are interdependent. Then, with a sentence that could easily have been uttered by John Muir or Rachel Carson, Dr. King stated, It really boils down to this: that all life is interrelated.

title: Diane Straus, Publisher of Liberal Policy Magazines, Dies at 66
description: Diane Straus, the publisher of two liberal policy magazines who was also a championship platform tennis player, died on Wednesday at her home in Washington. She was 66.

title: McConnell Wryly Calls Bannon a Genius
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Mitch McConnell took a sarcastic shot on Friday at Stephen K. Bannon, telling reporters at an end-of-the-year news conference that Mr. Bannons political genius had cost the party a Senate seat in Alabama.

title: Jeanine Pirro of Fox News Helps an Old Friend: President Trump
description: A few years ago, not long after Jeanine Pirro paid a visit to Donald J. Trump at his Trump Tower office, a box arrived at her home in Rye, N.Y.

title: Perus President Hangs On to Power, but at What Cost?
description: LIMA, Peru  The president of Peru is safe, for now.

title: The End of Miss America
description: During the summer nights in Provincetown, Mass., pedestrians and passers-by are treated to a show. As the sun sets, the queens come out. The heels are high; the hair is higher, the makeup expertly applied, turning the performers into amplified versions of Cher, or Barbie, or Lady Gaga, or creatures of their own invention.

title: U.S. Backs Honduran Presidents Victory in Disputed Election
description: MEXICO CITY  The United States government recognized President Juan Orlando Hernndez of Honduras as the winner of last months disputed election on Friday amid angry protests by Hondurans who believe the vote count was fraudulent.

title: Quotation of the Day: Homeowners Hurrying to Soften Tax Laws Bite
description: Im getting swamped with many, many calls, usually one an hour, from people who want to prepay their taxes.

title: Convicted Bomber Tried to Radicalize Fellow Inmates, Officials Say
description: Federal prosecutors said on Friday that the New Jersey man convicted of detonating explosives in the Chelsea section of New York in September 2016 that injured more than 30 people has been attempting to radicalize fellow inmates at the Manhattan jail where he is being held pending his sentencing.

title: The Ugly Business of Beauty Apps
description: You dont have to get a digital nose job in order to be a person online, but a lot of app companies strongly suggest you do.

title: Coaches Dream of Glory. I Root for That Dream.
description: One of the first things that disappears when you write about sports for a living is fandom. Its a necessary sacrifice. The teams you grew up watching with your parents, your siblings and your best friends become part of the job.

title: The Rise of the Ironic Racist
description: White supremacists used to hide their faces under hoods. But todays internet-savvy racists are shielding themselves behind the plausible deniability of meme culture.

title: The White Internets Love Affair With Digital Blackface
description: All across the internet, white people feel empowered to play around with black identity.

title: Daring Deed
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  For some reason, there were a lot of clues in this Matthew Sewell puzzle that put me in a good humor. A themeless puzzle should rove far and wide in its references, so you cant expect to hit your own personal little jackpot every time and come away with something memorable, but this one spoke to me a few times.

title: Appeals Court Rules Against Latest Travel Ban
description: A federal appeals court ruled Friday against President Trumps latest travel ban, saying that it exceeds the scope of his delegated authority, but that it was ultimately for the Supreme Court to decide.

title: Corrections: December 23, 2017
description: NATIONAL

title: Bruce McCandless, First to Fly Untethered in Space, Dies at 80
description: Bruce McCandless, the first person to fly untethered in space, whose journey into the dark void above Earth was preserved in a famous photograph, died on Thursday. He was 80.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Good Time and Secrets of Christs Tomb
description: Robert Pattinson is a hothead in Good Time. And a new documentary shows the restoration of the shrine in Jerusalems Church of the Holy Sepulcher.

title: Merry Christmas. Now Who Swiped My Tree?
description: For Americas Christmas trees, it seems no place is safe. Spruces, firs and even artificial evergreens have vanished in recent weeks, leaving behind a trail of conifer crime scenes.

title: In Asias Fattest Country, Nutritionists Take Money From Food Giants
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Over the past three decades this increasingly prosperous nation has become the fattest country in Asia, with nearly half the adult population now overweight or obese. Several years ago, Dr. Tee E Siong, Malaysias leading nutrition expert, decided to act, organizing a far-reaching study of local diets and lifestyle habits.

title: Tropical Storm in Philippines Kills More Than 100 and Leaves Dozens Missing
description: MANILA  A tropical storm in the Philippines cut through a swath of the main southern island of Mindanao, killing at least 103 people and burying many in remote areas by landslides and mudslides just as families were preparing for Christmas, officials said Saturday.

title: For More Than 300 Afghan Children, Many Older Than 5, Home Is Mothers Cellblock
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan  Zakirullah, a 9-year-old boy, is one of hundreds of Afghan children in prison because their mothers are. Even his dreams seem bound to the cellblock.

title: Erdogan Trains His Broom on a Sweep of Turkeys Governing Party
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Looking ahead to elections next year, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has been conducting a vigorous housecleaning, pledging a serious renewal of his governing party.

title: What Happens When You Report Sexual Harassment?
description: Producer: Nilo Tabrizy | Graphics: Andrew Jordan | Senior Producer: Sameen Amin | Executive Producer: Mark Scheffler

title: The Anti-Protest Gear That Despots Love
description: China-based Norinco is a state-owned defense company that markets a military-grade crowd-control system complete with water cannons and tear gas launchers. Experts say its overkill, but at least one customer  Venezuela  disagrees.

title: Not Everyone Is Jolly About Christmas Trees in the Lobby
description: Q. We live in a large Upper West Side co-op built in the 1960s as middle-income housing. However, newer residents are typically much wealthier than longtime ones. Over the last few years, there has been a marked increase in Christmas decorations in the lobby  large Christmas trees, poinsettias and other items. But half of the residents are Jewish, and some tenants feel unwelcome by the extensive and opulent Christmas display.

title: Weaving Around the World
description: From Venice to Addis Ababa, the West Bank to the Navajo Nation reservation, follow the process of weaving, which has been developed across cultures for thousands of years.

title: In Bethlehem, a Mood of Hopeless Resignation Among Palestinians
description: BETHLEHEM, West Bank  A Christmas tree inside the doorway beckoned travelers to the Jacir Palace Hotel, a luxury inn in the West Bank city of Bethlehem.

title: A Catskills Inn Gets a Modern Makeover
description: Rooms from $145; suites from $400.

title: I Was Not Going to Accept It: After Captivity, Blind Syrian Forges Path to U.S.
description: Hope often came in subtle waves of clarity for Amier Agha. He would recall his younger brothers new, prosperous life in San Francisco, which invariably made him think of images he had seen of sprawling metropolises and the New York City skyline. The thoughts filled him with warmth and wonder.

title: A Peruvian Chef Makes a Striking Los Angeles Comeback
Listen to Dear Sugars: Cutting the Financial CordWith Dr. Kate Gale
description: My son and I had a falling out two and a half years ago, begins a letter from a divorced father calling himself Father of Three, Acquaintance of One. My legal responsibility for financially supporting him ends next year when he turns 18. I could certainly opt to continue providing that support but should I?

title: The Daniel Day-Lewis Version of Fantasy Fashion Diva
description: Much has been made in recent weeks of Phantom Thread, the Paul Thomas Anderson movie about a 1950s couturier that opens, like a big present for us all, on Christmas Day. That is mostly because its star, Daniel Day-Lewis, has announced loudly that it will be his last film, and because his last collaboration with Mr. Anderson, There Will Be Blood, about the oil business, was such a power punch of a flick (and won Mr. Day-Lewis his second Oscar for best actor).

title: Harry Potter and the Magical Profit Margins Under the Tree
description: Ive long been under the spell of Harry Potters wand. Not the one in the books or the movies, but the Chinese-made wands you can buy for $37.50 at Amazon, or $42.95 from harrypottershop.com.

title: Who Wants to Buy the Most Expensive House in America?
Holiday Madness in Midtown Manhattan
description: For many adults, this time of the year is dominated by to-dos: buying thoughtful gifts, decorating the house, wrapping up work projects ahead of vacation, practicing self-control around food and drinks and the crazy uncle youd love to tell off.

title: Parts of Puerto Rico Wont Have Power for 8 Months. Whats the Holdup?
description: Some mountainous areas of Puerto Rico are going to be without electricity for as long as eight months, the United States Army Corps of Engineers said this week. It has been three months since Hurricane Maria swept through the island, knocking down tens of thousands of power poles and turning off virtually everyones lights. The amount of power being generated there is at about 65 percent of capacity  and it has been stuck around that level since late November.

title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
description: My, my  only one more week until 2018. (Were purposely not reminding you how much time you dont have left before Christmas.) Between wrapping gifts and wrapping up your New Years Eve plans, take a minute or an hour to invest in your intellect. Here are some of the best stories you may have missed.

title: Brazil Wavers on Environment, and Earths Largest Wetland Starts to Wither
description: MIRANDA, Brazil  Brazils booming soy industry and cattle ranches are threatening one of the richest wildlife havens on the planet, where packs of jaguars, caimans, marsh deer and macaws have roamed freely for eons.

title: Pit Bull Restrictions Lifted in Montreal as New Mayor Makes Good on Pledge
description: Just a few months ago, Renaud Begin worried that Montreal, the city he lives in, was trying to take his dog away from him.

title: Trump Gives Presidential Challenge Coin a Makeover, and It Shows
description: Whats big and shiny and gold and features Donald J. Trumps name splashed across the front? No, its not a new development on the West Side of Manhattan. Its the redesigned presidential challenge coin.

title: Afghan Governor Refuses to Leave His Post, Escalating Showdown
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A powerful Afghan governor fired by the countrys president refused on Saturday to leave a post he has held for 13 years, raising fears that the escalating political tensions could undermine the countrys fragile security.

title: On Christmas Eve in Ukraine, the Church Is Chilly (or Is It?)
description: The 12 of us around the kitchen table said our prayers individually in hushed tones.

title: Yemens War Enters a Dark Stage as Rebels Squeeze the Capital
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The rebels who control Sana, the capital of Yemen, have tightened their grip on the city and its people in recent weeks, shutting off access to the internet, blocking social media sites and sending gunmen to raid the homes of anyone they suspect of opposing them.

title: London Zoo Fire Kills Aardvark; 4 Meerkats Are Missing
description: LONDON  The London Zoo reopened on Sunday after more than 70 firefighters battled a blaze that destroyed a gift shop and cafe, killed an aardvark and left some staff members suffering from smoke inhalation, the zoo said.

title: A Colorblind Artist? Yes, With a Little Help From His Friends
description: After the best-selling childrens books illustrator Loren Long finished a Facebook live art video in The Times studio, his publicist noticed a viewer comment from Mr. Longs brother. He says youre colorblind, she said, shocked. Mr. Long admitted it was true. He had never talked about his colorblindness publicly, he said.

title: Parallel Lives Until Something Clicked
description: Annie Lynne Lee and Landon Spiller Dickey were married Dec. 15. Jane Kim, a member of San Franciscos board of supervisors, officiated at San Francisco City Hall.

title: As Prince Accelerates Changes for Women, Saudis Adapt at Varied Pace
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Saudi Arabia has long been known as one of the worlds most restrictive environments for women, where they could not travel alone, hold a wide range of jobs, show their hair in public or drive. That is beginning to change.

title: Rupert Murdoch and President Trump: A Friendship of Convenience
description: The calls to the White House come at least once a week. Murdoch here, the blunt, accented voice on the other end of the line says.

title: Yugoslavia Tribunal Leaves Rich Legacy, but Immense Challenges Remain
description: THE HAGUE  Embarrassed by its failure to prevent Europes worst atrocities since World War II, the United Nations Security Council created a tribunal in 1993 to track down and punish those responsible for the horrific violence against civilians that convulsed the Balkans during the breakup of Yugoslavia.

title: The Las Vegas Gunman Was Rich. Will His Wealth Go to the Victims?
description: The Las Vegas gunman Stephen Paddock stands out among American mass killers because of his wealth. He became a millionaire, according to his family, through the buying and selling of real estate and through skillful high-stakes gambling.

title: Trumps Tough Immigration Talk Meets Reality
description: As ICE arrests have gone up, deportations have gone down. Why? Its partly because of the complex realities of a tough policy put in practice.

title: Stoking Fears, Trump Defied Bureaucracy to Advance Immigration Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  Late to his own meeting and waving a sheet of numbers, President Trump stormed into the Oval Office one day in June, plainly enraged.

title: Variety: Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Do people do the Sunday crossword puzzle before the variety, or vice versa, as a rule? They dont usually share a theme, but it is the most symbolic time of the year, after all. This week I did the crossword first, so I should have been tuned in for an appearance by RUDOLPH and his crew, not just in the clues but in the quotation and the title of the book that the quotation came from.

title: At Vice, Cutting-Edge Media and Allegations of Old-School Sexual Harassment
description: One woman said she was riding a Ferris wheel at Coney Island after a company event when a co-worker suddenly took her hand and put it on his crotch. Another said she felt pressured into a sexual relationship with an executive and was fired after she rejected him.

title: Mariah Carey Will Return to New Years Rockin Eve After Last Years Meltdown
description: Following a spectacular flameout of a performance moments before the ball dropped in Times Square last year, Mariah Carey is giving New Years Eve another chance.

title: Vice Media Statement on Harassment Allegations and Workplace Culture
description: On Friday, Vice Media provided a statement to The New York Times in response to questions about its workplace culture. On Saturday, the company distributed to its staff members a longer version of the statement that follows below.

title: In a First, U.N. Evacuates Dozens of Refugees from Libya to Italy
description: Dozens of refugees and migrants who were held in detention in bleak conditions in Libya were evacuated to Italy late on Friday night, according to the United Nations refugee agency.

title: Why Did No One See the Tet Offensive Coming?
description: When the Tet offensive ignited South Vietnam on Jan. 30, 1968, American forces were taken by surprise. Every one of the countrys 44 provinces was hit in a stunning, coordinated attack that changed the course of the war. With so many American resources in Vietnam focused on intelligence-gathering, why was the United States so clueless? My own experience with the United States Agency for International Development might shed some light on this lapse.

title: Sexuality, Sex Abuse and Sexism
description: To the Editor:

title: Flying Saucers and Other Fairy Tales
description: I am completely in favor of federal spending on U.F.O. research, an outlay whose existence was revealed to surprisingly little paranoid excitement by this newspaper last week. It is a sign of civilizational health to devote excess dollars to the scientific fringe, and to hope that bizarre secrets still await discovery even in our satellite-surveilled world. So good for Harry Reid and his little-green-men-obsessed billionaire pal for keeping the flame of weird curiosity alive.

title: For Russian Artists in 1917, Art Was the Thing, Not Revolution
description: MOSCOW  On Feb. 27, 1917, the artist Boris Kustodiev looked out the window from his wheelchair onto a square in Petrograd (today St. Petersburg) and watched a group of celebrating revolutionaries passing by.

title: Free Detained Journalists in Myanmar
description: On Dec. 13, Myanmars Ministry of Information released a photograph of two handcuffed men who had been arrested for simply doing their job. They were Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo, two journalists who work for Reuters and who were arrested on the order of Myanmars president, Htin Kyaw, a day earlier on the outskirts of Yangon where theyd gone to meet two policemen from Rakhine State. They havent been seen or heard from since.

title: Bus Plunges Into River in India, Killing Dozens
description: At least 33 people died on Saturday when a bus plunged off a bridge in the western Indian state of Rajasthan, according to a local news reports.

title: The DeVos Nice List
description: WASHINGTON  It pays to be a cause that Education Secretary Betsy DeVos cares about.

title: Arseny Roginsky, Russian Human Rights Leader, Is Dead at 71
description: MOSCOW  Arseny Roginsky, the longtime leader of the Russian human rights organization Memorial and a Soviet-era dissident who documented the victims of state persecution during the Cold War and after, died on Monday in Tel Aviv. He was 71.

title: Im Struggling to Survive: For Rohingya Women, Abuse Continues in Camps
description: KUTUPALONG, Bangladesh  Rahimas father never wanted her out of his sight. She and her sister were too young, too pretty, too vulnerable to be trusted among the men of her village in western Myanmar, not to mention the soldiers who roamed the region.

title: Hiep Thi Le, Vietnamese Refugee Who Became Film Star, Dies at 46
description: Hiep Thi Le, who escaped Vietnam on a fishing boat when she was about 9 and a dozen years later became an unlikely movie star when she was cast as the central figure in Oliver Stones 1993 film Heaven and Earth, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. She was 46.

title: Andrew McCabe, F.B.I.s Embattled Deputy, Is Expected to Retire
description: WASHINGTON  The F.B.I.s embattled deputy director, Andrew G.
