title: Is LeBron James, at 33, Better Than He Was 5 Years Ago?
description: LeBron James turns 33 on Saturday, and you dont need advanced statistics to tell you that he is still playing amazingly.

title: At George Washington Bridge, a Fence Rises to Deter Suicides
description: Capt. Emilio Gonzalez read, aloud, some statistics for 2017. He repeated one: Sixty-eight saves.

title: Dealing With Subway Panhandlers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Town Turns the Tables on Traffic Apps
description: To the Editor:

title: Germans Will Ring in New Year With Extra Security, Especially for Women
description: BERLIN  While Germans are stocking up on firecrackers and Champagne to welcome the New Year, officials are setting up roadblocks and safety zones for women to ensure that festivities in cities across the country remain peaceful and safe.

title: Tech and Racial Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: Unfiltered Fervor: The Rush to Get Off the Water Grid
description: SAN FRANCISCO  At Rainbow Grocery, a cooperative in this citys Mission District, one brand of water is so popular that its often out of stock. But one recent evening, there was a glittering rack of it: glass orbs containing 2.5 gallons of what is billed as raw water  unfiltered, untreated, unsterilized spring water, $36.99 each and $14.99 per refill, bottled and marketed by a small company called Live Water.

title: Keeping the Family Tree Alive
description: What keeps venerable old families together? They are, after all, only as strong as the roots that bind them.

title: Sue Grafton, Whose Detective Novels Spanned the Alphabet, Dies at 77
description: Sue Grafton, a prolific author of detective novels known for an alphabetically titled series that began in 1982 with A Is for Alibi, died on Thursday night in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 77.

title: Why Are All Our Words in Bubbles?
description: They arrive in rectangular bubbles with rounded edges.

title: Donald Trump and the Limits of the Reality TV Presidency
description: As with most politicians, Franklin D. Roosevelt loved attention and approval in equal measure. Once, after watching himself in a newsreel, he remarked, That was the Garbo in me. On meeting Orson Welles, the president said, You know, Orson, you and I are the two best actors in America!

title: Separating the Good Honey From the Bad
description: Maribel Ramirez, 37, is a quality assurance assistant at Nature Nates Honey in McKinney, Tex.

title: Action Bronson, the Leader of the Most Joyously Disorienting Show on Late Night
description: Action Bronson began a recent episode of The Untitled Action Bronson Show in the barber chair. In the corner of the studio, cobblers were building shoes. The comedian DeRay Davis arrived with some Chicago-style pizza that failed to impress. Eh, its all right, Bronson said with a shrug. Then, a yoga session began, and after a couple of minutes, he lit a blunt.

title: Deaths in 2017: Among the Luminaries, Fighters With a Cause
description: In 1989, Liu Xiaobo left a comfortable visiting scholarship at Columbia University to return to his native China and thrust himself into a maelstrom.

title: Sharing an Office With Keebler Characters
description: Easy access and sunny reflections

title: For Congestion Pricing Plan, New Support and Steadfast Critics
description: The closest subway station to Bob Friedrichs home in eastern Queens is 10 miles away, so he drives to work in Manhattan at least three times a week.

title: America, Can We Talk About Your Drinking?
description: After a season of indulgence, many Americans resolve to drink less in the new year. Its a common pledge  many of us can recall cringe-worthy texts sent after a raucous night out or a regrettable comment uttered after that third glass of wine.

title: An Antidote to Digital Dehumanization? Live Theater
description: I recently learned that a group of neuroscientists have discovered that watching live theater can synchronize the heartbeats of an audience. One of the researchers put it this way: Experiencing the live theater performance was extraordinary enough to overcome group differences and produce a common physiological experience.

title: Wrapping Up a Year of Fund-Raising
description: The philanthropic set capped off 2017 with the Metropolitan Museum of Arts Acquisitions Fund Benefit on Dec. 14. The Berggruen Institute awarded Baroness Onora ONeill with its $1 million Berggruen Prize for Philosophy and Culture at the New York Public Library on the same evening. And the New York Botanical Garden held its 19th annual Winter Wonderland Ball at the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory on Dec. 15.

title: Jets Put Positive Spin on 5 Wins, and Bring Back Bowles and Maccagnan
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jets tight end Austin Seferian-Jenkins pointed a thumb over his shoulder to a piece of paper taped to the inside of his locker. It was a printout of an ESPN article that projected the Jets would go 0-16 this season.

title: Nintendos Switch Brings Some Magic Back
description: Jake Kazdal, an American video game developer who lives in Kyoto, Japan, spent a night in early March refreshing the website of GameStop, the video game retail chain in the United States. He wanted to buy Nintendos just-released console, the Switch. But the device had already sold out in Japan, forcing him to look elsewhere.

title: 2017: Our Reporters Reflect on Covering Washington and Politics
description: It would be an understatement to say that 2017 was one of the most exciting years in American politics in decades.

title: Readers Respond to Deliverance From 27,000 Feet
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Bronx, New Years, I.R.S.: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Three Months After Maria, Roughly Half of Puerto Ricans Still Without Power
description: For the first time in the 100 days since Hurricane Maria slammed Puerto Rico, the government finally knows how many people still dont have power: about half.

title: Kenichi Yamamoto, Father of Mazdas Rotary Engine, Is Dead at 95
description: Kenichi Yamamoto, who led the engineering team that produced a commercially viable rotary engine at the company now known as Mazda Motor Company and later became its president and chairman, died on Dec. 20 in Kanagawa Prefecture, near Tokyo. He was 95.

title: In the Bronx, History Repeats Itself With Deadly Force
description: To a strangers knock, a boy of about 9 opens the door of 1022 Woodycrest Avenue, the Bronx. He listens for a moment, then circles back to summon his mother, Manthia Magassa. The warming fragrance of a stew has drifted from the kitchen, then streams in to the cold doorway. An electronic chirp sounds from the wooden stairwell. The boy watches television.

title: New Liqueur Adds Tart Citrus Flavors to Cocktails
description: Yuzu, the lemony citrus fruit thats a staple in Japan, provides the essential flavor and aroma for Yuzuri, a new Japanese liqueur. The whole fruit  peels, juice and pulp  steeps for a month in a spirit made from rice. The liqueur is then lightly sweetened. The result is almost colorless, with a flavor thats citrusy, hinting of lemongrass and more tart than sweet. Id keep it on the bar to add a new dimension to tart-sweet cocktails like a sidecar or a whiskey sour: Yuzuri, $37.99 for 750 milliliters, Hi-Time Wine Cellars, Costa Mesa. Calif., hitimewine.net.

title: Dont Let Lasagna Fool You. This Pan Is the Whole Enchilada.
description: Lagostina, an Italian cookware company in the Piedmont region, was started in 1901 as a tin-plating factory. Today the company specializes in handmade cookware like this new lasagnera, a stainless steel pan designed for lasagna and the other savory dishes like moussaka and enchiladas that the season demands. It has a cherry wood cover: Lagostina Lasagnera, $199.95, Williams Sonoma stores, williams-sonoma.com.

title: Pumpkin Preserves for the Cheese Plate
description: The pumpkin preserves from Murrays Cheese will give quince paste (membrillo) some mellow competition on the cheese plate. The preserves are made in Armenia and combine a somewhat crisp texture with earthy richness: Murrays Preserved Pumpkin, $7.99 for 10.9 ounces, Murrays Cheese, 888-692-4339, murrayscheese.com.

title: Why Im Still a NeverTrumper
description: Tax cuts. Deregulation. More for the military; less for the United Nations. The Islamic State crushed in its heartland. Assad hit with cruise missiles. Troops to Afghanistan. Arms for Ukraine. A tougher approach to North Korea. Jerusalem recognized as Israels capital. The Iran deal decertified. Title IX kangaroo courts on campus condemned. Yes to Keystone. No to Paris. Wall Street roaring and consumer confidence high.

title: Judge Says Pennsylvania Election Districts Give Republicans an Edge, but Are Not Illegal
description: A Pennsylvania judge said Friday the states Congressional districts were drawn to give Republicans an advantage, but they did not violate the state Constitution, ruling in a high-profile gerrymandering case with the potential to have major consequences on the 2018 midterm elections.

title: Broths for Sipping or Souping
description: Its soup season, and here are some newcomers for which the graphic designers worked overtime cramming the hype (Broth is cool! Hey everyone drink broth!) all over the packages. The brand, Rocket Broth, offers a chicken bone broth and vegan broth, both made in Brooklyn from mostly organic ingredients. Sheryl Moller, a certified health practitioner and nutrition guide, and Cree LeFavour, a cookbook writer, created the broth line. Sold in stand-up pouches, the broths are pleasant and modestly flavorful (230 to 250 milligrams of sodium help) for drinking or using in recipes. The chicken bone broth has a hefty 16 grams of protein per cup: Rocket Broth, $13.99 for 24 ounces, sold frozen, myrocketbroth.com.

title: Christmas May Be Over, but Holiday Shopping Is Not
description: Gina Mezzacappa avoided the mall for her holiday shopping, but an ill-fitting pair of Michael Kors boots brought her back this week.

title: 10 Falsehoods From Trumps Interview With The Times
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump, in an impromptu interview on Thursday with The New York Times, rattled off at least 10 false or misleading claims about the Russia investigation, wars abroad, health care, immigration and trade. Heres an assessment.

title: Le Bernardin Adds a Vegetarian Tasting Menu
description: There has always been an occasional vegetable or meat dish served at Le Bernardin, which has featured mostly seafood from the day Maguy and Gilbert Le Coze opened it in Paris in 1972. Now Eric Ripert, the restaurants executive chef since 1994 and then partner, is introducing the restaurants first vegetarian tasting menu. I often get a dozen inquiries a week for a vegetable tasting, he said. I like the idea of a menu that pays homage to the vegetable, though its a creative challenge. The menu has six savory courses and two desserts. Standouts include celeriac soup served in a whole celeriac, a twist of pasta thatched with black truffles, a roulade of zucchini and caponata, and roasted porcini alongside eggplant that is both silky and crisp: Vegetarian tasting menu, $185 a person, Le Bernardin, 155 West 51st Street (Seventh Avenue), 212-554-1515, le-bernardin.com.

title: Delving Into the Religious Symbolism of Candy
description: On the religious side of the holiday season, and indeed across the calendar, there are any number of traditional sweets with sacred meanings. Constance Kirker, a culinary historian and retired professor of art history at Penn State who now teaches at the Culinary Institute of America in Singapore, will address the topic Sacred Sweet Tooth: The Symbolism and Function of Candy and Sweets in Religious Traditions as it pertains to Christianity, Hinduism, Buddhism and Islam. The talk is sponsored by the Culinary Historians of New York. Sweets will be served: Sacred Sweet Tooth, Jan. 15 at 6:30 p.m., $25 for members, $40 for nonmembers, $10 for students, eventbrite.com; Culinary Historians of New York, Anthroposophical Society of America, 138 West 15th Street (Seventh Avenue), culinaryhistoriansny.org/events/.

title: Our Reporter Mike Schmidt on His Golf Club Interview With President Trump
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Shortly after 1 p.m. on Thursday, President Trump came off the 18th hole of his golf course here and walked into the club houses Grill Room. Waiters scurried to bring menus and drinks to a large round table reserved for him as he stopped to shake hands and make small talk with members eating lunch.

title: What Happened at the Bronx Fire
description: A fire tore through an apartment building in the Bronx on Thursday night, killing at least 12 people on multiple floors.

title: In Deadly Bronx Blaze, Responders Battled Fire and Ice
description: The frozen hydrant in front of the burning building. The icy steps tripping up firefighters as they carried people out. The frigid front and rear fire escapes cramped with dozens of people clambering to safety.

title: City of the Future? Humans, Not Technology, Are the Challenge in Toronto
description: TORONTO  For a city striving to become a major technology center, it was a prize catch: A Google corporate sibling would spend the coming year planning a futuristic metropolis in a derelict part of Torontos waterfront.

title: Behind the Phoenix Program
description: In late December 1967, the government of South Vietnam announced a reorganization of its war effort against the countrys Communist insurgency. Effective immediately, all South Vietnamese counterinsurgency activities became part of a new program known as Phuong Hoang, a reference to a magical bird associated with royalty and power in Vietnamese and Chinese cultural traditions. In response to the South Vietnamese move, American officials in Vietnam began referring to their own counterinsurgency coordination efforts by the name that they deemed the closest Western analogue to the mythical creature: Phoenix.

title: Summoned by a Prank Call, Police in Wichita Kill a Man at His Front Door
description: The call to the police sounded dire: a violent dispute at a house in Wichita, Kan., a person shot to death, an armed man holding hostages and threatening to burn the place down.

title: Quotation of the Day: Soldier Died Trying to Save One More
description: I need somebody to tell me what to feel. Where do I go from here? Four at one time  what do I do?

title: Dont Cheer as the I.R.S. Grows Weaker
description: No federal agency generates as much rancor as the Internal Revenue Service, part of that duo of inevitability, taxes and death. Despite its reputation for toughness, the I.R.S. relies on voluntary compliance, as in Americans sense of duty, to collect the money that powers our government.

title: 20 Great Reads You Probably Missed in 2017
description: There was a lot of news in 2017  just take a look at the 750 breaking news alerts The New York Times sent this year, a 30 percent jump from last year. So we understand if you might have missed some of these great reads. Heres a selection of some of our favorite somewhat-overlooked stories from the past year.

title: Corrections: December 30, 2017
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Free Your Mind? Black Mirror Isnt Too Hopeful
description: The following essay includes plot points for episodes of Black Mirror, including Season 4, which arrived on Dec. 29 on Netflix.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: High Maintenance and Mean Girls
description: Meet eccentric New York personalities through the wandering HBO series High Maintenance. And catch the teenage comedy Mean Girls before it leaves Netflix in January.

title: For Young Coaches, Tradition Is Among the Toughest Opponents
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland  When the second goal went in, Ian Cathro felt a shift. Cathro, the Heart of Midlothian coach, had not given up on the game: His team was down by only 2-1 to visiting Dunfermline in their Scottish League Cup match, with much of the second half to play. There was still more than enough time to draw level, perhaps even go on to win.

title: Pandas, U.F.O.s and Other Curiosities from Britains National Archives
description: LONDON  The sporadic release of documents from Britains National Archives gives a glimpse into the countrys inner workings. For instance, there was the revelation that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher debated using the military to quell a miners strike in 1984.

title: The BBC in Pidgin? People Like It Well-Well
description: The headline on the article, published on the BBCs website, reads like this: Woman wan troway poo-poo, come trap for window.

title: Some Afghan Children Find an Alternative to Jail  for Now
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  On visiting days in the womens wing of Pul-e-Charki prison in Kabul, Najia Nasim would regularly see a little girl named Dahlia waiting outside her mothers cell, standing up straight, wearing a small backpack. Inside the backpack were all of the girls clothes and a few personal possessions.

title: Can I Divide My Apartment Into Two?
description: Q. My wife and I have lived in a prewar co-op on the Upper West Side since 1985. In 1996, we purchased the neighboring unit, combining the two apartments to enlarge our living space. We are both seniors now and no longer need so much space. Are there any city laws or codes that would prohibit us from redividing the apartments and returning them to their original configurations so that we could sell one and remain in the other?

title: In Certifiably Happy Norway, a Cranky Traveler Finds Some Bliss (Within Reason)
description: The big white mountain goats lazed on a path of an alpine park last August overlooking Bergen, Norways second largest city, where a crowded funicular had taken us to the top.

title: London Tours Meant to Surprise and Entertain
description: Winter may not be Londons peak tourist season, but travelers with plans to head to the city in the coming colder weather months can look forward to a lineup of new tours that are far from run of the mill. Whether its your first time in London or youre a repeat visitor, these seven city tours are meant to unearth perspectives on a perennially popular destination that both surprise and entertain.

title: Why Are Mutual Fund Fees So High? This Billionaire Knows
description: The billionaire investor Ronald S. Baron flashed the grin of a proud father at his annual investor jamboree in November, as the chief executives of his favorite companies explained how slashing prices stoked their bottom lines.

title: Where Are the American Women in Olympic Figure Skating?
description: Can it be close to 20 years since Tara Lipinski, then 15, upset Michelle Kwan at the 1998 Winter Games in Nagano, Japan, to become the youngest Olympic figure skating champion?

title: Brains, Hearts and Heroin Addiction: Medicine in VR
description: Addiction treatment, heart surgery and brain research are just some of the areas where virtual reality is helping to improve traditional approaches to treatment and training in medicine. Step inside a human heart or experience addiction treatment in VR.

title: Inside the Hollywood Home of Social Medias Stars. (Dont Be Shy.)
description: LOS ANGELES  On any given day, something crazy is likely to be happening at 1600 Vine Street, a 550-unit apartment complex in Hollywood.

title: Kazakhstan Prizes Its Cowboys, but Few Want to Saddle Up for Harsh Life
description: KERBULAQ, Kazakhstan  It has been a long, rough ride for the cowboys of Kazakhstan, descendants of the nomadic herders who roamed across Central Asia until Russia declared in 1864 that it could no longer tolerate their turbulent and unsettled character and would force them to settle down.

title: China to Try Tibetan Education Advocate Detained for 2 Years
description: Chinese officials are planning to put Tashi Wangchuk, who advocates broader Tibetan language education, on trial next week for inciting separatism, a charge that could result in a sentence of up to 15 years in prison, according to his lawyers.

title: 10 of Our Best Weekend Reads + One Great Video
description: This weekend is one for reflecting and looking ahead; for family, friends and football; for sleeping in and starting things off right; for bundling up and bingeing on good (or bad) TV. Whatever youre doing, take a minute, or a bit more, and indulge in some great journalism. Happy New Year!

title: The Most Vexing Unanswered Questions of 2017
description: The year was littered with mysteries. Still, we suspected we knew many of the answers already. Are dogs smarter than cats? Yes and, no offense, but theres a reason so many anthropomorphized pets are pooches. Did the Pentagon secretly sort of believe in aliens? Fox Mulder made us all want to believe back in the 90s. Was Hollywood corrupt? Sure thing! If even more so than wed imagined.

title: Dont Call It Street Style
description: In a photograph by Sara Hylton, a confident woman stands in profile for a portrait. Wearing a patterned shirtdress and gleaming brass jewelry, she exudes style. What is not immediately apparent is that the picture was shot in South Sudan, a young, war-torn country where even carrying a camera in public is dangerous.

title: Battle Royale Over Rightful Heir to Israeli Self-Defense Discipline
description: NETANYA, Israel  More martial than art, this form of fighting extols the virtues of a poke in the eye and a timely kick to the groin. Its masters insist it is not a sport, because there are no rules, except for one: to survive.

title: Iran Confronts 3rd Day of Protests, With Calls for Khamenei to Quit
description: Irans leaders were confronted by unauthorized protests in major cities for the third straight day on Saturday, with crowds aiming their anger at the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and some demanding that he step down.

title: Tesla the Car Is a Household Name. Long Ago, So Was Nikola Tesla.
description: A Tesla is an electric car. Just about everybody knows that.

title: Born for Each Other
description: Abby Ren Olivier and Earp Franklin Jennings were married Dec. 30 at Christ Episcopal Church in Little Rock, Ark. The Rev. J. Scott Walters, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Kate Alexander, also an Episcopal priest, taking part.

title: Origami-Style Cardboard Tents for Homeless in Brussels
description: With material tents forbidden on the streets of Brussels, homeless people in the Belgian capital are often left without a safe place to sleep. But one entrepreneur seems to have found a way around the rule: origami-style cardboard tents.

title: Why Children Play With Fire, and How to Stop Them
description: The fire that killed 12 people at an apartment building in the Bronx on Thursday night was started by a 3-year-old boy who was playing with the burners on a stove  which he had done before, his mother told investigators. The cause was heart-wrenching, but the behavior not that uncommon.

title: Our Country Deserves Your Respect, Not Your Pity
description: WASHINGTON  Once again, Haiti, a country with deep historical ties to the United States, is in the news. Once again, a negative narrative permeates the public dialogue and Haitian people are compelled to defend our humanity. Once again, the circumstances require us to wage a battle on two fronts: tackling the physical rebuilding of our nation so that future generations can prosper, while simultaneously combating prejudice and stigma that risk being, over time, institutionalized in the American consciousness.

title: How the Russia Inquiry Began: A Campaign Aide, Drinks and Talk of Political Dirt
description: WASHINGTON  During a night of heavy drinking at an upscale London bar in May 2016, George Papadopoulos, a young foreign policy adviser to the Trump campaign, made a startling revelation to Australias top diplomat in Britain: Russia had political dirt on Hillary Clinton.

title: The Best of The Daily in 2017
description: Ten great episodes that illustrate how The Daily, hosted by Michael Barbaro, uses storytelling to explain the biggest stories of the day to a fast-growing, devoted audience.

title: Puns and Anagrams
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Mel Taub returns with a fun Puns and Anagrams puzzle. This flu is kicking my behind, so Im going to leave you all to discuss this one amongst yourselves.

title: Republican Attacks on Mueller and F.B.I. Open New Rift in G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  A growing campaign by President Trumps most ardent supporters to discredit the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, and the law enforcement agencies assisting his investigation is opening new fissures in the Republican Party, with some lawmakers questioning the damage being done to federal law enforcement and to a political party that has long championed law and order.

title: Why an Upstate Prisoner With a History of Escape Foiled His Latest
description: The plan sounds ingenious.

title: In Fire-Scarred Bronx Neighborhood, a World of New Arrivals, Children and Community
description: Even on a nose-numbingly cold morning, families were out on the sidewalks around Prospect Avenue. A mother tugged a beanie over her squiggling sons ears, and girls ran down the block. They were trailed by a boy towing a wagon filled from a trip to the store, his younger brother wedged in with produce and paper towels.

title: It Was His Life or Mine: A Drastic Plan Altered Her Course
description: The man would not leave Jacqueline Torres alone.

title: The Best Photo Books of 2017
description: There are great photo books every year, and 2017 was no exception. But something about the strained times intensified my feelings about the work I saw this year. The role of art felt more urgent, both as a response to the general political disorder and as a refuge from it. I didnt merely like or appreciate the best work I saw; I needed it. The photo books that made my list range from large scholarly catalogs to poetic little volumes. They were published in seven different countries. Some were more conceptual in approach, while others were freer and more visceral. These winners all had in common the special qualities of great photo books: the pleasure of turning pages, the precision of thoughtful book design, the tactility of paper and the glow of the afterimages in the mind long after the book is set down.

title: Trump Ends Terms of Remaining Members of H.I.V. and AIDS Council
description: The Trump administration this week dismissed the remaining members of a federal advisory council on H.I.V. and AIDS. The groups executive director said the move was a common occurrence in new administrations, but others questioned that.

title: The U.S. Has Pummeled Al Qaeda in Yemen. But the Threat Is Barely Dented.
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  The United States has tripled the number of airstrikes this year against Al Qaedas branch in Yemen, one of the deadliest and most sophisticated terrorist organizations in the world. American allies have pushed the militants from their lucrative coastal strongholds. And the Pentagon recently boasted of killing key Qaeda leaders and disrupting the groups operations.

title: Nepal Bars Solo Climbers From Mount Everest
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  Nepal has barred solo climbers on its mountains, including Mount Everest, in an attempt to promote safety and reduce accidents, an official said on Saturday.

title: The #MeToo Moment: The Year in Gender
description: As sexual misconduct scandals continue to unfold, our gender team is providing updates and analysis in a new newsletter. Read previous installments here and sign up here to receive future newsletters.

title: Republicans 2018 Resolution: Bipartisanship. Will It Last?
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Mitch McConnell sounded downright magnanimous in anticipation of 2018, eager to work closely with Democrats even though he had cut them out of virtually every big-ticket deliberation during 2017.

title: A Tiny Vermont Town Is a Big Cradle of Olympians
description: The road to the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, runs through Norwich, a hilly and wooded family-oriented farming community tucked between Interstates 89 and 91 in rural Vermont. With a main street lined with white clapboard colonial buildings and a landmark steepled church, Norwich could be a set designers rendering of a tiny New England village.

title: Erica Garner, Activist and Daughter of Eric Garner, Dies at 27
description: Erica Garner, the daughter of Eric Garner who became an outspoken activist against police brutality after her fathers death at the hands of a New York police officer, died on Saturday, according to her mother. She was 27.

title: Ask Roxane: Is It Too Late to Follow My Dreams?
description: I love advice columns, always have. Growing up, I read Dear Abby and Ask Ann Landers. I enjoyed the voyeurism  glimpses into the lives and troubles of others  and I appreciated the steady, practical advice as if truly, for any problem, there was a solution. Giving advice is nearly as satisfying: the simple pleasure of offering counsel and hoping that you are helping in some small way.

title: Guns and Domestic Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Confessions of a Columnist
description: Every year at this time I join a growing number of journalistic flagellants in enumerating things that I got wrong in the previous annums worth of columns. When I started the practice, the annual audit sometimes felt a little bit too scrupulous, like picking nits with my own work. But the last two years have been different: As Donald Trumps ascent turned all sorts of supposed wisdom into folly, Ive found myself with a great deal of mistaken analysis to acknowledge and live down.

title: Higher Eds Low Moment
description: When all was said and done, the tax overhaul that President Trump signed into law a little more than a week ago didnt beat up on higher education to the extent that earlier drafts of the legislation did. Americans who were deducting interest on student loans will still be able to do so. The tuition waivers that many graduate students receive wont be treated as income.

title: When Forecasters Get It Wrong: Always
description: To borrow from Yogi Berra, it is tough to make predictions, especially about the future. But 2017 was particularly difficult. On many of the biggest forecasts  global growth, inflation, the trajectory of the big powers  the experts got the year wrong.

title: Theres No Place Like This Rent-Stabilized Home
description: As if New Years Eve isnt wonderful enough, its also the night Im getting kicked out of my apartment. Ive had a magical year, a year of living in a gorgeous two-bedroom apartment overlooking Prospect Park, in Brooklyn, for the same price as my previous place in East Harlem, which I shared with a lovely roommate and his disrespectful cat, Bobbi.

title: Dad Believed in U.F.O.s. Turns Out He Wasnt Alone.
description: The year now ending has been so laden with tumultuous news that one astounding report in the exhausted final days of 2017 seemed almost routine: that for years, an intelligence official burrowed within the Pentagon warren was running a secret program to investigate reports of unidentified flying objects.

title: A D.J. Could Save Your Life Tonight
description: On New Years Eve, youll be dancing, one hopes. If youre lucky youll be dancing to an honest-to-God disc jockey  not to someones Spotify playlist or the musings of the latest demi-celebrities to fancy themselves party conductors. A real D.J. is part shaman, part tech-wizard, part crowd psychologist, all artist. Many people claim the title but far fewer embody it.

title: 2 Men Charged in Quadruple Homicide in Troy; Motive Is a Mystery
description: Two suspects have been charged in a quadruple homicide in Troy, N.Y., a crime the police chief described as the worst he had seen in more than 40 years in law enforcement.

title: The Gamblers Ruin of Small Cities (Wonkish)
description: Im on vacation, keeping vague track of the news but basically taking a break and spending a lot of time communing with nature. But Ive also been thinking a bit about economics, taking advantage of psychological distance to ruminate on stuff that isnt closely connected to the news. And one of the areas Ive been chewing over goes back to my old stomping ground of economic geography.

title: John Portman, Architect Who Made Skylines Soar, Dies at 93
description: John Portman, the architect and developer who revolutionized hotel designs with soaring futuristic atriums, built commercial towers that revitalized the downtowns of decaying postwar American cities and transformed Asian skylines from Shanghai to Mumbai, died on Friday in Atlanta. He was 93.

title: Early Hall of Fame Voting for 2018 Shows No Surge for Bonds and Clemens
description: A year ago, a change of heart among Baseball Hall of Fame voters gave a boost to the drug-tarnished candidacies of Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens, although it did not win them induction, or even get them that close.

title: Coming Out in Lebanon
description: Throughout the Arab world, gay, lesbian and transgender people face formidable obstacles to living a life of openness and acceptance in conservative societies.

title: How Can Trump Help Irans Protesters? Be Quiet.
description: WASHINGTON  As anti-government rallies gather momentum across Iran  taking outside analysts and the Iranian government alike by surprise  President Trump and his foreign policy advisers are likely asking what they can do to support the protesters.

title: Romania Braces for Presidents Decision on Bills Seen as Weakening Judiciary
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  Across Eastern Europe, liberal values were under threat in 2017, with governments in countries like Hungary, Poland and Romania passing measures intended to push back against democratic principles, including anticorruption efforts, freedom of the press and the rule of law.

title: A Year of Animal Oddities Around the World: 7 Reader Favorites
description: The animal kingdom is full of wondrous, wild and weird stories.

title: Ring Out the Old, Ring In the New
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Even though John Lampkins puzzle publishes online on Saturday, it is technically the last crossword of the calendar year, so its fitting that he chose the concept of ringing out the old and ringing in the new as his theme.

title: Glitch in South Carolina Lottery Could Mean $19.6 Million in Winnings
description: Streams of winning lottery tickets were printed in South Carolina because of a computer glitch on Christmas Day, officials said, and the potential winnings could total as much as $19.6 million if they are validated.

title: Quotation of the Day: U.S. Pounds Al Qaeda in Yemen, but Barely Dents Risk of Attack
description: Still the worlds most dangerous man.

title: Congo Reports Arrest in Killing of 2 U.N. Experts
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  A man suspected in the killing of two United Nations experts in the Democratic Republic of Congo was arrested early Saturday, according to Congolese authorities.

title: Corrections: December 31, 2017
description: ARTS & LEISURE

title: Greek Prime Minister Seeks to Block Asylum for Turkish Officer
description: ATHENS  An independent Greek government committee decided on Saturday to grant political asylum to a Turkish officer who fled last years failed coup in his country. The decision provoked an immediate angry response from Turkey, and hours later the Greek prime ministers administration moved to block it.

title: Katherine Davis, Michael Golden
description: Katherine Maddox Davis and Michael Garrett Golden are to be married Dec. 31 at First Baptist Church in Tallahassee, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Douglas Dortch, a Baptist minister, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Ann Nguyen, Andrew Dewhurst
description: Dr. Ann Thuy Nguyen and Andrew Joseph Dewhurst Jr. were married Dec. 30 at St. Patrick Church in Tacoma, Wash. The Rev. Tuan Nguyen, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Kelly Jones, Daniel Howell
description: Kelly Elizabeth Jones and Daniel Ray Howell were married Dec. 30 at St. Marys Catholic Church in Manhasset, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Peter LeJacq, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Susan Romeo, Peter Moesta
description: Susan Lee Romeo and Peter Friedrich Moesta are to be married Dec. 31 at the Nassau Inn in Princeton, N.J. Carmen Alvarez, an appellate division judge with chambers in Cape May, N.J., is to officiate.

title: Marisa Franklin, Raphael Graybill
description: Marisa Meredith Franklin and Raphael Jeffrey Carlisle Graybill are to be married Dec. 31 at the University Lutheran Church in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Jessica Crist, a Lutheran bishop and the mother of the groom, is to lead the ceremony.

title: Alicia Franck, Brinkley Serkedakis
description: Alicia Ann Franck and Ann Brinkley Serkedakis were married Dec. 30 at Felicity Church in New Orleans. The Rev. Patricia Snyder, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Jessica Perez, Daniel Suvor
description: Jessica Naomi Perez and Daniel Ramsey Suvor were married Dec. 29 at St. Monica Catholic Church in Santa Monica, Calif. Msgr. LLoyd Torgerson performed the ceremony.

title: For Trump, a Year of Reinventing the Presidency
description: WASHINGTON  When President Trump meets with aides to discuss policy or prepare for a speech, he may ask about the pros and cons of a new proposal. He may inquire about its possible effect. He may explore the best way to frame his case.

title: Elizabeth Nugent, Nicholas Lotito
description: Elizabeth Ryan Nugent and Nicholas John Lotito were married Dec. 30 at Roia Restaurant in New Haven. Katherine R. Christopher, a justice of the peace in Clinton, Conn., officiated.

title: Erica Andersen, Jonathan Donenberg
description: Erica Nicole Andersen and Jonathan Michael Donenberg are to be married Dec. 31 at the International Trade Center in Washington. Rabbi Joshua Beraha is to officiate.

title: Merav Silverman, Ian Ramsay
description: Merav Heettner Silverman and Ian Spicer Ramsay are to be married Dec. 31 at the Minneapolis Event Center in Minnesota. Rabbi Irwin Kula is to officiate.

title: Bette Marston, Brian Canter
description: Elizabeth Holloway Marston and Brian Spencer Canter are to be married Dec. 31 at the Tampa Museum of Art in Florida. The Rev. Thomas R. Cook, an Episcopal priest and a cousin of the bride, is to officiate.

title: Ava Bastian, Stephanie Lizza
description: Ava Catherine Bastian and Stephanie Kaye Lizza are to be married Dec. 31 at 26 Bridge, an events space in Brooklyn. Rabbi Michael Ramberg, a cousin of the bride, is to officiate.

title: Kira Ramani, Kevin Hernandez
description: Kira Nicole Ramani and Kevin McLeod Hernandez were married Dec. 30 in South Pasadena, Calif. Msgr. Clement J. Connolly performed the ceremony at Holy Family Church, with the Rev. Timothy R. Scully, also a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: Rosanna Perretta, Robert Menna
description: Dr. Rosanna Christina Perretta and Robert John Menna are to be married Dec. 31 at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas E. Collins, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Anthony Sibilia, Joseph Marino
description: Anthony Michael Sibilia and Joseph Frank Marino Jr. are to be married Dec. 31 at the Mansion at Tuckahoe, an events space in Jensen Beach, Fla. Dev Ghose, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Whats on TV Sunday: New Years Eve Celebrations and Dave Chappelle
description: Mariah Carey will return to Times Square for New Years Eve. Two Dave Chappelle specials come to Netflix.

title: Rouhani Urges Calm in Iran as Protests Continue
description: After four days of rare protests that shook Iran, President Hassan Rouhani tried to calm the nation on Sunday, saying that people had the right to protest and acknowledging public concerns over the economy and corruption.

title: A Year in Bloopers: The Making of The Daily 360
description: Happy New Year from the Daily 360 team! We've made 435 videos in 426 days. Here are some of the moments that didnt make the cut. Pro tip: If you can see the camera, the camera can see you.

title: Homes That Sold for Less Than $500,000
description: 140 East 95th Street, No. 4E, Carnegie Hill

title: On the Dance Beat: Extreme Focus, Extreme Costumes, Extreme Imagination
description: It has become routine to talk about mindfulness, but as a dance writer, Ive been putting it into practice for years. Thats what you do when you watch a dance. You focus your total awareness on the present.

title: New Years Eve, Iran, Donald Trump: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories, and a look ahead.

title: Laughter, Then Horror, as Flames Engulfed Upscale Mumbai Restaurants
description: MUMBAI, India  Aksheeta Doshi Shroff and a few family members were relaxing at 1 Above, a rooftop restaurant in a trendy district of Mumbai, when a small fire broke out shortly after midnight on Friday.

title: In Congo, 8 Killed and Altar Boys Arrested Amid Crackdown on Protests
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  At least eight people were killed and a dozen altar boys arrested in the Democratic Republic of Congo on Sunday after security forces cracked down on planned church protests against President Joseph Kabilas refusal to leave office before coming elections.

title: Even in Poland, Workers Wages Flow to North Korea
description: POLICE, Poland  At an isolated shipyard on Polands Baltic coast, men in coveralls used welding torches under a cold drizzle, forging an oil tanker for a customer in the Netherlands. The scene was unremarkable, save for the provenance of a dozen of the workers.

title: Passing the Torch to the Next Generation of Volunteers
description: James Robinson was explaining how he ended up in his own ambulance, not in front at the wheel, but in the back, injured.

title: Colorado Gunman Shoots 5 Officers Near Denver, One Fatally
description: It began as a predawn call for the police to a disturbance at an apartment complex in a Denver suburb on Sunday. It ended, officials said, in a fusillade of more than 100 rounds fired by a barricaded gunman who shot five law enforcement officers, killing one of them. The gunman was killed by officers.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 17 at Funeral in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber walked into a cemetery in eastern Afghanistan on Sunday and blew himself up during the funeral of a local official, killing at least 17 people and wounding 14 others, an official said.

title: Merkels Wishes for 2018: More Empathy and a New Government
description: BERLIN  Angela Merkel of Germany, addressing her country as an acting chancellor, pledged in her annual New Years address on Sunday to work for all Germans and to swiftly form a new government to help ensure success into 2018 and beyond.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

title: Fire Department Finds a Way Around Times Square Traffic for Medical Emergencies
description: An ambulance, with its siren wailing and lights flashing, was unable to move, stuck in gridlocked traffic one recent afternoon along Eighth Avenue in Times Square. Some drivers tried to get out of the way even as pedestrians hurried past. But it was too late. The light changed and vehicles from a nearby street spilled onto the clogged roadway, causing further congestion.

title: After 2nd Bout With Cancer, Seeking to Heal His Body and Mind
description: Because he was in such a hurry to get to his granddaughters high school graduation, James Riddick did not realize he had forgotten his cane until he reached the bus.

title: The Acrobatic Artwork That Pretty Much Sums Up 2017
description: Every once in a while with Twitter, you find something that breaks through the bilge and recrimination. Or, sometimes something finds you. One night, The Mechanics of History found me. Its an art installation by Yoann Bourgeois that sat in a daylit rotunda at the Panthon, in Paris. And for a long while in late fall, I found myself mesmerized by a video of it, starring men spinning off a staircase and onto a trampoline.

title: Rohingya Children Facing Massive Mental Health Crisis
description: BALUKHALI, Bangladesh  Jehora Begum was a fast runner, racing through rice paddies and splashing through canals.

title: The Month in Live Jazz: 5 Standout Shows
description: The true way to experience improvised music is live. More than in most other art forms, jazzs big discoveries and developments have historically happened onstage: The musics creation depends on an engaged, participating audience. With that in mind, were starting this column, recapping the most outstanding live jazz performances Ive seen over the past month. Im hoping that it will offer some clues as to where jazz is headed these days  and maybe even encourage you to go out and hear it for yourself.

title: Charles Dutoit Replaced at New York Philharmonic Concerts After Assault Allegations
description: Joshua Weilerstein will conduct a series of New York Philharmonic concerts in January, after Charles Dutoit stepped down from the podium following sexual assault allegations.

title: Ringo Starr Tapped for Knighthood
description: Ringo Starr has been named a knight. The Beatles drummer was selected for knighthood by Queen Elizabeth II in her 2018 New Years Honors list, along with Barry Gibb of the Bee Gees and the author Michael Morpurgo. The ballet dancer Darcey Bussell has been named a dame.

title: Manchester City Avoids Defeat but Not Injuries
description: LONDON  After a record run of 18 successive wins in the Premier League, only a penalty save in stoppage time enabled Manchester City to escape its first defeat of the season Sunday at 17th-place Crystal Palace.

title: We Will Carry You
description: Australia Diary is a weekly collection of reader stories (and images and videos) reflecting Australias unique character. Share yours with us and check out our previous installments.

title: Dan Talbot, Impresario of Art Films, Is Dead at 91
description: Dan Talbot, one of the most influential figures in the world of art-house film as an operator of Manhattan theaters  including Lincoln Plaza Cinemas, which is scheduled to close on Jan. 28  and a founder of the film distribution company New Yorker Films, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: Review: Ending the Year With a Pair of Early-Music Ensembles
description: Two of New Yorks established early-music ensembles plied specialties over the weekend, a study in contrasts despite basic similarities.

title: New Slaughtering Rules Pit Dutch Religious Freedoms Against Animal Rights
description: AMSTERDAM  For 60 years, the Sal Meyer deli in Amsterdam has been serving kosher foods like its signature pekelvlees, a fatty corned beef steeped in meat juices and served with a bun.

title: Cruise Ships Have Made Bar Harbor Popular. But Have They Ruined It?
description: BAR HARBOR, Me.  Residents of this scenic coastal town have struggled for the last several years with a conundrum familiar to anyone living in a beautiful place that attracts tourists: How do you maintain its essence when crowds threaten the very qualities they come to enjoy?

title: Last Jedi Is 2017s Box Office Winner in a Women-Led Year
description: LOS ANGELES  Sorry, Batman. So close, yet so far away, Star-Lord. Better luck next time, Captain Jack Sparrow.

title: Tax Law Offers a Carrot to Gig Workers. But It May Have Costs.
description: The new tax law is likely to accelerate a hotly disputed trend in the American economy by rewarding workers who sever formal relationships with their employers and become contractors.

title: Sabres Return to Spotlight for the Winter Classics 10th Anniversary
Louisiana Man Charged in Nigerian Prince Scheme
description: The Nigerian prince letter, one of the better-known frauds, is often perpetrated by mysterious figures. But the police in Louisiana say theyve put a face and a name to a man and charged him with more than 200 counts related to the scheme.

title: From Trump to #MeToo: A Dizzying Year in TV News
description: A cable-news-obsessed president turned TV journalists into household names. A nationwide reckoning on sexual harassment ended the careers of some of televisions best-known personalities. And Americans, seeking clarity amid the noise, turned to networks like Fox News and MSNBC in record numbers. Two New York Times media reporters analyze 2017, the year when TV roared back.

title: How Do You Turn an Ad Into a Meme? Two Words: Dilly Dilly
description: In 1995, a nation was rapt as three frogs croaked the syllables in Budweiser. Four years later, Budweiser prompted countless television viewers to wag their tongues and ask their friends, Whassup?

title: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: Goddess of Anarchy
description: Lucy Parsons would stand out today, so one can imagine the scene she created as a woman in the second half of the 19th century espousing anarchy for the purpose of overthrowing capitalism. An African-American born into slavery, Parsons grew up to fashion a story about herself, claiming to be the daughter of Mexican and Native American parents. In her new biography, Goddess of Anarchy, Jacqueline Jones writes that Parsons rejected a personal historical or ethnic identity in favor of presenting herself as the champion of the laboring classes; that, she thought, was all that people needed to know about her. Ms. Jones, who won the Bancroft Prize in 1986 for her book Labor of Love, Labor of Sorrow: Black Women, Work, and the Family, from Slavery to the Present, teaches in the history department at the University of Texas at Austin. Below, she talks about the new information she unearthed about Parsons, the way Parsons captivated crowds and much more.

title: How a Reporter and Victims Families Went Beyond the Horror of 2 Kansas Hate Crimes
description: The Reader Center is one way we in the newsroom are trying to connect with you, by highlighting your perspectives and experiences and offering insight into how we work.

title: Partisans, Wielding Money, Begin Seeking to Exploit Harassment Claims
description: WASHINGTON  As the #MeToo movement to expose sexual harassment roils the nations capital, political partisans are exploiting the moment, raising hundreds of thousands of dollars to support accusers who come forward with charges against President Trump and members of Congress, even amid questions about their motivation.

title: The World Celebrates New Years Eve
description: In Sydney, rainbow fireworks sparkled off the Harbour Bridge in celebration of Australias recent legalization of gay marriage. (Sydney was among the first major cities to celebrate with fireworks at the stroke of midnight.)

title: How Do You Vote? 50 Million Google Images Give a Clue
description: What vehicle is most strongly associated with Republican voting districts? Extended-cab pickup trucks. For Democratic districts? Sedans.

title: Democrats in High-Tax States Plot to Blunt Impact of New Tax Law
description: Democrats in high-cost, high-tax states are plotting ways to do what their states representatives in Congress could not: blunt the impact of the newly passed Republican tax overhaul.

title: On the Way to the Doctor
description: Dear Diary:

title: Torch Song Pentalogy
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Some of you will be reading this before the New Year, and some of you will be reading this when its 2018. This post is always tricky to pin down for everyone, so let me pre-emptively and retroactively wish you all a Happy New Year. I hope that no matter how you plan to or did celebrate, fun will be or was had by all, at the time it was actually had.

title: Courts Must Better Police Themselves on Harassment, Chief Justice Says
description: WASHINGTON  Responding to the retirement of a prominent appeals court judge accused of sexual harassment, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. said the federal court system must do more to protect law clerks and other employees from abusive conduct.

title: Fatal Swatting Episode in Kansas Raises Quandary: Who Is to Blame?
description: When the police surrounded a house in Wichita, Kan., late Thursday, they expected to find a gunman who told a 911 dispatcher that he was holding his mother and brother at gunpoint after shooting his father in the head.
